{{TennisEventInfo|2009|Abierto Internacional Varonil Casablanca Cancún| | date=16 – 22 November | edition=2nd | location=[[Cancún]], [[Mexico]] | champs={{flagicon|CHI}} [[Nicolás Massú]] | champd={{flagicon|GER}} [[Andre Begemann]] / {{flagicon|POR}} [[Leonardo Tavares]] }}
The '''2009 [[Abierto Internacional Varonil Casablanca Cancún]]''' was a professional [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Tennis court#Clay courts|outdoor red clay courts]]. It was the second edition of the tournament which was part of the [[2009 ATP Challenger Tour]]. It took place in [[Cancún]], Mexico between 16 and 22 November 2009.
==ATP entrants==
===Seeds=== {|class="sortable wikitable" |- ! width="70"| Country ! width="175"| Player ! Rank<sup>1</sup> ! Seed |- |{{flag|POR}} |[[Rui Machado]] | 118 | 1 |- |{{flag|SLO}} |[[Blaž Kavčič]] | 121 | 2 |- |{{flag|ESP}} |[[Pere Riba]] | 127 | 3 |- |{{flag|CHI}} |[[Nicolás Massú]] | 134 | 4 |- |{{flag|SLO}} |[[Grega Žemlja]] | 154 | 5 |- |{{flag|MEX}} |[[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]] | 166 | 6 |- |{{flag|AUT}} |[[Andreas Haider-Maurer]] | 181 | 7 |- |{{flag|MON}} |[[Benjamin Balleret]] | 214 | 8 |}
* Rankings are as of November 9, 2009.
===Other Entrants=== The following players received wildcards into the singles main draw: * {{flagicon|USA}} [[Jordan Cox (tennis)|Jordan Cox]] * {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Daniel Garza]] * {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Tigre Hank]] * {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Bruno Rodríguez (tennis)|Bruno Rodríguez]]
The following players received entry from the qualifying draw: * {{flagicon|SUI}} [[Adrien Bossel]] * {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Philippe Frayssinoux]] * {{flagicon|USA}} [[Eric Nunez]] * {{flagicon|USA}} [[Greg Ouellette]] * {{flagicon|POR}} [[Pedro Sousa]] ([[Lucky Loser|LL]])
==Champions==
===Singles=== {{main article|2009 Abierto Internacional Varonil Casablanca Cancún – Singles}} {{flagicon|CHI}} '''[[Nicolás Massú]]''' def. {{flagicon|SLO}} [[Grega Žemlja]], 6–3, 7–5
===Doubles=== {{main article|2009 Abierto Internacional Varonil Casablanca Cancún – Doubles}} {{flagicon|GER}} '''[[Andre Begemann]]''' / {{flagicon|POR}} '''[[Leonardo Tavares]]''' def. {{flagicon|USA}} [[Greg Ouellette]] / {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Adil Shamasdin]], 6–1, 6–7(6), [10–8]
==External links== *[http://www.itftennis.com/mens/tournaments/tournamentSearch.asp ITF search] *[http://www.protennislive.com/posting/2009/4041/x.pdf 2009 Draws]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{quote box|width=400px|align=right|quote="UEFA will be demanding the harshest of sanctions before the competent courts for any individuals, clubs or officials who are implicated in this malpractice, be it under state or sports jurisdiction."|source='''UEFA General Secretary [[Gianni Infantino]], 20 November 2009.<ref name=UEFA1/>'''}} The '''2009 European football betting scandal''' was an attempt to [[match fixing|influence the outcome]] of professional [[association football]] matches in Europe, and to defraud the gambling industry by betting on the results.<ref name=guard1>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/nov/20/uefa-match-fixing-germany|title=Europe hit by 'biggest-ever' match-fixing scandal|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=21 November 2009|date=20 November 2009 | location=London | first=Owen | last=Gibson| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091123171042/http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2009/nov/20/uefa-match-fixing-germany| archivedate= 23 November 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref> The investigation centres on around two-hundred fixtures, including domestic league games in nine European countries: Germany, Belgium, Switzerland, Croatia, Slovenia, Turkey, Hungary, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Austria.<ref name=BBC1/> It also involved twelve qualifying matches in the [[UEFA Europa League]], and three in the [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref name=UEFA1>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefa/keytopics/kind=64/newsid=922086.html |title=UEFA statement on match-fixing case |publisher=[[UEFA]] |accessdate=21 November 2009 |date=20 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091123061118/http://www.uefa.com/uefa/keytopics/kind%3D64/newsid%3D922086.html |archivedate=23 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Peter Limacher, a spokesman for European football's governing body [[UEFA]], described it as "the biggest match-fixing scandal ever to hit Europe."<ref name=BBC1>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8370748.stm|title=Match-fixing inquiry probes 200 European football games|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=21 November 2009|date=20 November 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120303175141/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8370748.stm| archivedate=3 March 2012| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Background== {{quote box|width=250px|align=right|quote="If results are fixed in advance, football has no further reason to exist."|source=[[Michel Platini]].<ref name=guard2/>'''}} The 2009 European football betting scandal was considered to be the biggest affair in European football since the [[Bundesliga scandal (2005)|2005 football scandal]] of referee Robert Hoyzer and the [[Bundesliga scandal (1971)|Bundesliga-scandal]] in the 1970/71 season when numerous players, coaches and officials were involved in game shifts. The extent and effects were regarded as even greater than in the previous manipulations in football.<ref name="Wettskandal">{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/betrugsverdacht-bei-200-spielen-riesiger-wettskandal-erschuettert-europas-fussball-a-662480.html |title=Riesiger Wettskandal erschüttert Europas Fußball |last1=Glindmeier |first1=Mike |last2=Korge |first2=Johannes |date=20 November 2009 |publisher=Spiegel |access-date=6 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> Some newspapers refer to this scandal as the "biggest fraud scandal of all time" and Peter Limacher, head of the disciplinary department of [[UEFA]], spoke of it as the "biggest fraud scandal ever in European football".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://diepresse.com/home/sport/fussball/523142/Fussball_Der-grosste-Betrugsskandal-aller-Zeiten |title=Fußball: Der größte Betrugsskandal aller Zeiten |last1=Leingruber |first1=Martina |date=20 November 2009 |publisher=Die Presse |access-date=6 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
According to information from the Bochum prosecutor's office on 20 November 2009, at least 200 football matches had been manipulated in nine European countries since the beginning of 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/sport/wettskandal-im-fussball-die-gekauften-tore-der-profikicker-1.151061 |title=Die gekauften Tore der Profikicker |date=17 May 2010 |publisher=Süddeutsche Zeitung |access-date=6 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> The fraudsters had bribed players, coaches and officials to influence gameplay.
The two Croatian brothers Ante and Milan Sapina were arrested on 19 November 2009 and held responsible for fraud involving the betting manipulated games in Asia (provider: SBOBET with license in the Philippines<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/tid-16317/fussball-manipulationen-osnabruecker-abstieg-herbeigepfiffen_aid_456051.html |title=Fußball-ManipulationenOsnabrücker Abstieg herbeigepfiffen? |last1=Derichs |first1=Gregor |date=20 November 2009 |publisher=Focus |access-date=6 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> and Europe, totaling about 10 million Euro. They had already been given a prison sentence after the 2005 football scandal.<ref name="Wettskandal" /> A further 15 persons were arrested in Germany.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.welt.de/welt_print/politik/article5282346/Wettskandal-Groesster-Betrug-der-Fussball-Geschichte.html |title=Wettskandal: Größter Betrug der Fußball-Geschichte |last1=Müller |first1=Oliver |date=21 November 2009 |publisher=WeltN24 |access-date=6 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> More than 50 [[Search and seizure|house searches]] were carried out in [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], [[Baden-Wurttemberg]], [[Bavaria]], [[Berlin]], [[Lower Saxony]], [[Schleswig-Holstein]], Switzerland, Austria and the United Kingdom. Cash and assets of more than one million Euro were ceased.<ref name="Wettskandal" />
The UEFA European Football Association suspended the Ukrainian referee Oleg Orijechow, in connection with the betting scandal, and who had supposedly been in personal contact with a member of the betting mafia, according to Spiegel Online. He was summoned to Nyon for a personal hearing at the Federation Center following an investigation by UEFA's anti-corruption unit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/fussball-wettskandal-uefa-suspendiert-ukrainischen-schiedsrichter-sandhausen-entlaesst-schuon-a-664364.html |title=Uefa suspendiert ukrainischen Schiedsrichter, Sandhausen entlässt Schuon |last1=Wulzinger |first1=Michael |date=30 November 2009 |publisher=Spiegel |access-date=6 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> UEFA revealed in March 2009 that they were bringing charges against an unnamed European club, later revealed to be Macedonian side [[FK Pobeda]]. Pobeda were found guilty of match-fixing in a tie against Armenian club [[Pyunik]] in 2004. As a consequence, the club was handed an eight-year ban from all European competitions, and club president [[Aleksandar Zabrčanec]] and former captain Nikolce Zdravevski were given lifetime European football bans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/8004987.stm|title=Match-fix ban for Macedonian club|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=21 November 2009|date=17 April 2009}}</ref> UEFA president [[Michel Platini]] revealed that his organisation were stepping up their efforts to eradicate match fixing in the game, and that 27,000 fixtures would be monitored in the 2009–10 season.<ref name=guard2>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/mar/26/uefa-match-fixing-charges-platini|title=Uefa to bring match-fixing charges against mystery club|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=21 November 2009|date=26 March 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
The [[fraud]] was discovered through [[telephone tapping]] of [[organized crime]] activities and has been investigated by the Prosecutorial Office at [[Bochum]], Germany.<ref name=BBC1/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sta-bochum.nrw.de/presse/pressemit/index.php|title=Press release, Prosecutorial Office, Bochum|language=German|accessdate=3 December 2009|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120630093212/http://www.sta-bochum.nrw.de/presse/pressemit/index.php|archive-date=30 June 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 19 November 2009 a series of raids were conducted in the UK, Germany, Switzerland and Austria in relation to the betting investigation. They resulted in fifteen arrests in Germany, and a further two in Switzerland, as well as the seizure of cash and property.<ref name=BBC1/>
==Affected games and suspects==
===Germany=== In Germany at least 32 games from the [[2. Bundesliga]] to the junior area were manipulated. Including four games of the 2. Bundesliga, three games of the [[3. Liga]], 18 games in the [[Regionalliga]], [[Oberliga (football)|Oberliga]] games and two games from the U-19 division.<ref name="Fussball">{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/wettskandal-erklaerung-der-staatsanwaltschaft-im-wortlaut-a-662548.html |title=Erklärung der Staatsanwaltschaft im Wortlaut|date=20 November 2009 |publisher=Spiegel |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
In September 2010, the public-law TV magazine Fakt reported that thirteen 2nd and five 3rd league games, 20 regional league games, five league games, as well as, two games in the [[DFB-Pokal]], five U-19 games and other individual friendly games, were under suspicion of manipulation.
A DFB referee was also accused of having been bribed by the alleged fraudulent betters in a regional league game in May 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/fussball-wettskandal-auch-dfb-schiedsrichter-im-visier-der-ermittler-a-662561.html |title=Auch DFB-Schiedsrichter im Visier der Ermittler |date=21 November 2009 |publisher=Spiegel |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
In course of the investigation, basketball player of the [[Brose Bamberg|Brose Baskets]] from [[Bamberg]], Ivan Pavic,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pnn.de/titelseite/238405/ |title=Fußball-Wettskandal: Basketballer in Haft |date=23 November 2009 |publisher=Potsdamer Neueste Nachrichten |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> and the Würzburger landes league player, [[Kristian Sprećaković]], were also arrested on 19 November 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/sport/fussball/bundesliga/wettskandal-fussballprofis-im-zockermilieu-1582858.html |title=Fußballprofis im Zockermilieu |last1=Ashelm |first1=Michael |date=|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
Four games of the [[SSV Ulm 1846]] in the final phase of the Regionalliga season 2008/09 were under suspicion of manipulation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/wettskandal-dfb-schiedsrichter-im-visier-der-ermittler_aid_456123.html |title=Wettskandal: DFB-Schiedsrichter im Visier der Ermittler |date=21 November 2009 |publisher=Focus |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> On 27 November 2009, the club announced the denunciation of the Croatian players Davor Kraljevic, Marijo Marinovic and Dinko Radojevic in association with the betting scandal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/wettskandal-ssv-ulm-kuendigt-drei-spielern_aid_458108.html |title=Wettskandal: SSV Ulm kündigt drei Spielern |date=27 November 2009 |publisher=Focus |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
On 24 November 2009, [[Fußball-Regionalliga|football regional league club]] [[SC Verl]], suspended midfielders Patrick Neumann and Tim Hagedorn from games and training. The club received indications of attempted tampering for the game against Borussia Mönchengladbach II (4-3) and 1. FC Köln II (0-1) in the 2008/09 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ftd.de/sport/%3Awettskandal-festnahmen-verl-suspendiert-spieler/50041877.html |title=Festnahmen - Verl suspendiert Spieler |date=24 November 2009 |publisher=Financial Times Deutschland |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130206150331/http://www.ftd.de/sport/:wettskandal-festnahmen-verl-suspendiert-spieler/50041877.html |archivedate=6 February 2013 |df= }}</ref> On 28 November 2009, Neumann admitted to Bochum prosecutor's office that he receive 500 Euro, making him the first professional to sign a confession in the betting scandal. However, he continued to deny any activity in the manipulations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/wm-2010/national-wettskandal-erstes-spieler-gestaendnis_aid_458235.html |title=National: Wettskandal: Erstes Spieler-Geständnis |date=28 November 2009 |publisher=Focus |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
Defencemen [[Marcel Schuon]] confirmed to the Bochum prosecutor's office, that during his time at [[VfL Osnabrück]], manipulation took place in the second league game against FC Augsburg (0-3) on 17 April 2009. In which he refused to inform anyone of until after the game, which ended as planned 0-3, therefore Schuon was issued a five-digit fine. At the beginning of the 2009/10 season, Schuon switched to the third division team [[SV Sandhausen]], where he was removed by the team at the end of November 2009 due to his involvement in the betting scandal.
===Austria=== In Austria, 11 matches of the [[Austrian Football Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] and the [[Austrian Football First League|First League]] were affected.<ref name="Fussball" />
According to UEFA, no Austrian clubs were specifically involved in the betting scandal. Only two European League qualifying matches of the [[SK Rapid Wien]] against [[KF Vllaznia Shkodër|KS Vllaznia Shkodra]] (5-0 and 3-0 for Rapid) were suspected of manipulation according to press reports.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://derstandard.at/1256745648077/Ermittlungen-Rapid-Spiele-in-Wettskandal-involviert |title=Rapid-Spiele in Wettskandal involviert |date=25 November 2009 |publisher=Der Standard |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> At the beginning of March 2011, betting allegations about the Austrian Bundesliga club [[Kapfenberger SV]] were announced, where, according to various media reports, players of the club had been handed large sums of money, and accused of having perilously lost the [[2009–10 Austrian Football Bundesliga|2009/10 season]] games against [[FC Red Bull Salzburg]] (0-4), the [[SK Rapid Wien]] (0-1) and [[FK Austria Wien]] (0-1). Also at this time, a defensive player from [[Kapfenberg]], among others, was reported to have received €200,000 through a middleman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/int_ligen/international-ante-sapina-bestach-spieler-in-oesterreich_aid_605512.html |title=International: Ante Sapina bestach Spieler in Österreich |date=4 March 2011 |publisher=Focus |access-date=8 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
===Switzerland=== In Switzerland, 22 matches of the [[Swiss Challenge League|Challenge League]] and six test games were affected.<ref name="Fussball" /> At least one attempt to manipulate games of the [[Swiss Super League|Super League]] had occurred, but the addressed player reported the bribery attempt to the federation. Two suspects have been arrested.
====Suspicions towards games of FC Thun==== The federal prosecutor suspected [[FC Thun]] players to have manipulated the game against [[Yverdon Sport FC]] on 26 April. The suspicion was that FC Thun should lose the game with four goals difference, and the game actually ended 5-1. The Thun striker [[Pape Omar Faye]] was interrogated by the police, the week before the trophy game against Winterthur (22 November 2009) and then suspended by the club.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bernerzeitung.ch/sport/fussball/Faye-gehoert-nach-wie-vor-zu-unserer-Thuner-Familie/story/22226945 |title=«Faye gehört nach wie vor zu unserer Thuner Familie» |last1=Wäfler |first1=Alexander |date=25 November 2009 |publisher=BZ Berner Zeitung |access-date=9 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> Since a striker, from his playing position, can hardly be responsible for five goals against, other players were suspected of having received several 10,000 euros.
====Suspicions towards games of FC Gossau==== [[FC Gossau]] suffered a striking series of defeats at the end of the 2008/09 season. The federal prosecutor suspected specifically players of FC Gossau of having manipulated the games against FC Locarno on 24 May 2009 and against [[Servette FC]]. FC Gossau was expected to lose the game against Locarno with at least four goals difference and the game actually ended 0-4. The then goalkeeper of Gossau, Darko Damjanovic, was said have been taken into custody by police, but went undercover. Gossau’s midfielder, Mario Bigoni, publicly stated that a previous season's game was "not clean" and that he had received a bid from a fellow player.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vol.at/ex-fc-gossau-spieler-bigoni-verschwunden/3054622 |title=Ex-FC-Gossau-Spieler Bigoni verschwunden |date=14 October 2011 |publisher=Vorarlberg Online |access-date=9 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> Although it was not known if Bigoni had accepted the offer, he was suspended by his club. Also supposedly Gossau received tens of thousands of euros, 20,000 alone for the game against Locarno. On 26 October 2011, the police confirmed that Bigoni had been found dead three days earlier<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tagblatt.ch/ostschweiz/ostschweiz/tb-os/Ist-Mario-Bigoni-tot;art120094,2706039 |title=Ist Mario Bigoni tot? |last1=Kamber |first1=Marco |date=24 October 2011 |publisher=Tagblatt |access-date=9 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> in the [[Alter Rhein]] near [[Rheineck]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sport.orf.at/stories/2086333/ |title=Fußballprofi Mario Bigoni tot aufgefunden |date=26 October 2011 |publisher=ORF |access-date=9 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
====Test game==== The Bosnian club, [[NK Travnik]], completed a training camp in Switzerland in the summer of 2009, with test matches against the clubs [[Neuchâtel Xamax]] (2-3), Servette FC Genève (1-3) and [[FC Sion]] (1-4). It became known that a betting syndicate from Asia was financially involved in the costs of the training camp. The president of FC Sion, [[Christian Constantin]], publicly voiced the suspicions that the Bosnians let win FC Sion.
===China=== The Chinese police arrested a total of 16 people, including 12 club members and four high-ranking football officials, including the former vice president of the [[Chinese Football Association]], Yang Xu, on 25 November 2009, in the wake of the international inquiries of the betting scandal.<ref name="China">{{cite web |url=https://www.welt.de/welt_print/sport/article5332162/Wettskandal-Erste-Festnahmen-in-China.html |title=Wettskandal: Erste Festnahmen in China |date=26 November 2009 |publisher=WeltN24 |access-date=10 December 2016|language=German }}</ref>
===Matches investigated by UEFA=== All matches under investigation were played in 2009.<ref name=BBC1/> {|class="wikitable" |- !Competition or country !Number of games investigated !Level or round of competition |- |[[UEFA Champions League]]||3||Qualifying rounds |- |[[UEFA Europa League]]||12||Qualifying rounds |- |[[Football in Germany|Germany]]||32||[[2. Bundesliga]], [[3. Liga]], [[Regionalliga]], and [[Oberliga (football)|Oberliga]] |- |[[Football in Belgium|Belgium]]||17||[[Belgian Second Division|Second Division]] |- |[[Football in Switzerland|Switzerland]]||22||[[Swiss Challenge League|Challenge League]] |- |[[Football in Croatia|Croatia]]||14||[[Prva HNL]] |- |[[Football in Slovenia|Slovenia]]||7||[[Slovenian PrvaLiga|PrvaLiga]] |- |[[Football in Turkey|Turkey]]||29||[[Süper Lig]] |- |[[Football in Hungary|Hungary]]||13||[[Hungarian National Championship I]] |- |[[Football in Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia and Herzegovina]]||8||[[Premier League of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] |- |[[Football in Austria|Austria]]||11||[[Austrian Football Bundesliga|Austrian Bundesliga]] and [[Austrian Football First League|First League]] |- |[[UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]]||Unknown||Unknown |- |}
UEFA revealed on 25 November 2009 that seven matches played in UEFA competitions would be investigated in further detail, and that five clubs were under investigation; [[KF Tirana]], [[FC Dinaburg]], [[KS Vllaznia]], [[NK IB Ljubljana]] and [[Budapest Honvéd]]. It also revealed that it was conducting its own investigation of three referees and one other individual connected with UEFA in relation to these games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefa/keytopics/kind=64/newsid=924697.html |title=UEFA, FAs discuss match-fixing inquiry |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=25 November 2009 |date=25 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091128004339/http://www.uefa.com/uefa/keytopics/kind%3D64/newsid%3D924697.html |archivedate=28 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="China" />
====UEFA detailed on 7 manipulated games==== 2nd qualifying round for the Champions League * Stabaek IF – KF Tirana (4-0 on 21 July 2009)
2nd qualifying round for the Europa League * SK Rapid Wien - KS Vllaznia (5-0 on 16 July 2009) * Bnei Yehuda Tel Aviv F.C. - FC Dinaburg (4-0 on 16 July 2009) * KS Vllaznia - SK Rapid Wien (0-3 on 23 July 2009) * FC Dinaburg - Bnei Yehuda Tel Aviv F.C. (0-1 on 23 July 2009)
3rd qualifying round for the Europa League * Fenerbahce Istanbul - Budapest Honvéd (5-1 on 30 July 2009) * NK IB Ljubljana - Metalurg Donetsk (0-3 on 6 August 2009)
==Betting Scandal in Italy== Independent from the investigations conducted by the Bochum prosecutor's office, another betting scandal was reported in Italy on 23 November 2009. The President of the Italian football club [[Potenza S.C.|Potenza]], Giuseppe Postiglione, and eight other officials (including Antonio Lopiano and Antonio De Angelis) of Potenza, and Antonio Possidente, a member of [[the Mafia]], were arrested by the Carabinieri for tampering Football matches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/int_ligen/italien-wettskandal-in-italien-neun-festnahmen_aid_456608.html |title=Italien: Wettskandal in Italien: Neun Festnahmen |date=23 November 2009 |publisher=Focus |access-date=13 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.repubblica.it/2009/11/sport/calcio/calcioscommesse-potenze/calcioscommesse-potenze/calcioscommesse-potenze.html |title=Minacce e calcio scommesse arrestato presidente ragazzino |date=23 November 2009 |publisher=La Repubblica |access-date=13 December 2016 |language=Italian }}</ref> The several month long investigation involved a game of the [[Serie B]] in the 2007/08 season, as well as, seven games of the [[Lega Pro Prima Divisione]] in the 2008/09 season.
==Legal proceedings== On 14 April 2011, the 13th Criminal Court of the Bochum District, sentenced better Tuna A. and the betting office operator Stevan R., to three years and eight months and three years and eleven months, on the account of fraud. Betting office operator Nürretin G. was given a three-year prison sentence on the account of fraud. Tuna A. and Nurretin G. had already spent 13 months of their sentence while being held during examination. In the course of the trial, all three defendants had admitted to the manipulation of 32 games and of having bribed players.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nwzonline.de/fussball/hohe-haftstrafen-fuer-drei-wettbetrueger_a_1,0,631373460.html |title=Hohe Haftstrafen für drei Wettbetrüger |date=15 April 2011 |publisher=NWZ Online |access-date=14 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
In May 2011, Ante Sapina was sentenced to five and a half years' imprisonment by the District Court of Bochum. Marijo Cvrtak was also sentenced to five and a half years' imprisonment<ref>{{cite web |url=https://proxy.suma-ev.de/cgi-bin/nph-proxy.cgi/en/I0/http/www.wettbasis.com/sportwetten-news/urteilsverkundung-im-wettskandal-ante-sapina-ist-zu-funfeinhalb-jahren-haft-verurteilt-worden.html |title=Urteilsverkündung im Wettskandal: Ante Sapina ist zu fünfeinhalb Jahren Haft verurteilt worden! |date=20 May 2011 |publisher=wettbasis |access-date=14 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> and Dragan M. received a probation sentence of one year and six months.
In December 2012, the [[Federal Court of Justice]] declared the previous rulings against Sapina and an accomplices for non-appealable and dismissed them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/fussball-manipulationsskandal-prozess-gegen-sapina-wird-neu-verhandelt-a-874047.html |title=Prozess gegen Wettpaten Sapina wird neu verhandelt |date=20 December 2012 |publisher=Spiegel |access-date=14 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
In March 2013, Milan Sapina was sentenced to ten months' imprisonment by the district court of Bochum,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/583400/artikel_wettskandal_haftstrafe-fuer-milan-sapina.html |title=Wettskandal: Haftstrafe für Milan Sapina |date=18 March 2013 |publisher=kicker |access-date=14 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref> the sentence was largely waived in March 2014, leaving only a four-month imprisonment time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/wettbetrug-bgh-hebt-urteil-gegen-milan-sapina-auf-a-962703.html |title=BGH hebt Urteil gegen Milan Sapina auf |last1=Buschmann |first1=Rafael |date=5 April 2014 |publisher=Spiegel |access-date=14 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
In April 2014, Ante Sapina was sentenced to five years' imprisonment by the District Court of Bochum.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sport1.de/fussball/2015/03/wettpate-ante-sapina-muss-endgueltig-fuer-fuenf-jahre-hinter-gitter |title=Sapina muss endgültig ins Gefängnis |date=6 March 2015 |publisher=sport1 |access-date=14 December 2016 |language=German }}</ref>
==See also== *[[2011 Turkish sports corruption scandal]]
