[[Cotton Bowl Classic]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2010–present) | address = 1 AT&T Way{{cite web|url=http://stadium.dallascowboys.com/guests/guestInfo.cfm |title=Guest Info |publisher=Stadium.dallascowboys.com |accessdate=October 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029032225/http://stadium.dallascowboys.com/guests/guestInfo.cfm |archivedate=October 29, 2010 }} | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]1.3 billion{{cite news|last=Mosley |first=Matt |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/columns/story?columnist=mosley_matt&page=hotread1/mosley |title=Jones building a legacy with $1.3 billion Cowboys stadium |date=September 15, 2008 |accessdate=November 28, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030014350/http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/columns/story?columnist=mosley_matt&page=hotread1%2Fmosley |archivedate=October 30, 2008 }}
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|1300000000|2009}}}} in 2015 dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | seating_capacity = Football: 80,000 | Suites = 342{{cite web|url=http://www.seats3d.com/nfl/dallas_cowboys/#/level_4/ |title=Alternative content |publisher= |accessdate=10 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151212002930/http://www.seats3d.com/nfl/dallas_cowboys/ |archivedate=12 December 2015 |df= }} }} '''AT&T Stadium''', formerly '''Cowboys Stadium''', is a [[retractable roof]] stadium in [[Arlington, Texas]], United States. It serves as the home of the [[Dallas Cowboys]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) and was completed on May 27, 2009. It is also the home of the [[Cotton Bowl Classic]] and the [[Big 12 Championship Game]]. The facility, owned by the city of Arlington, can also be used for a variety of other activities such as concerts, basketball games, college and high school football contests, soccer matches, rodeos and [[motocross]] and Spartan races. It replaced the partially covered [[Texas Stadium]], which served as the Cowboys' home from 1971 through the 2008 season. The stadium is sometimes referred to as "'''Jerry World'''" after Dallas Cowboys owner [[Jerry Jones]], who originally envisioned it as a large entertainment mecca.[https://cowboyswire.usatoday.com/2018/05/29/dallas-cowboys-att-stadium-nfl-rankings] The stadium seats 80,000,{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumsofprofootball.com/nfc/AT&TStadium.htm |title=AT&T Stadium, Dallas Cowboys football stadium |publisher=Stadiums of Pro Football |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}} making it the fourth largest [[List of current National Football League stadiums|stadium in the NFL]] by [[seating capacity]]. The maximum capacity of the stadium with [[Standing-room only|standing room]] is 105,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/united_states/texas.shtml |title=Stadiums in the United States :: Texas |publisher=World Stadiums |date=2015-11-17 |accessdate=2017-03-27}} The record attendance for an NFL game was set in 2009 with a crowd of 105,121. The Party Pass (open areas) sections are behind seats in each end zone and on a series of six elevated platforms connected by stairways.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aqtlnqwjSsP8|accessdate=July 5, 2010|date=August 3, 2009|title=Dallas Cowboys Target NFL Record by Making Fans Stand for $29|publisher=Bloomberg.com}} It also has the [[List of largest video screens|world's 29th largest high definition video screen]], which hangs from 20-yard line to 20-yard line.{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2006/12/13/cowboys-new-stadium-to-get-over-20-000-square-feet-of-video-scr/|title=Cowboys' new stadium to get over 20,000 square feet of video screen|publisher=Engadget|accessdate=February 6, 2011}} ==Construction and design== [[File:Cowboys Stadium full view.jpg|thumb|280px|left|Interior]] Originally estimated to cost $650 million, the stadium's current construction cost was $1.15 billion,{{cite web|url=http://football.ballparks.com/NFL/DallasCowboys/newindex.htm|title=Cowboys Stadium|publisher=Football.ballparks.com|accessdate=February 6, 2011}} making it one of the most expensive sports venues ever built. To aid Cowboys owner and general manager Jerry Jones in paying the construction costs of the new stadium, Arlington voters approved the increase of the city's sales tax by 0.5%, the hotel occupancy tax by 2%, and car rental tax by 5%. The City of Arlington provided over $325 million (including interest) in bonds as funding,{{cite web|url=http://www.brb.state.tx.us/lgs_search.aspx?action=city |title=Local Government Services Database Search |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2012-10-19}} and Jones covered any cost overruns. Also, the NFL provided the Cowboys with an additional $150 million loan, following its policy for facilitating financing for the construction of new stadiums.{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2695427|title=Cowboys unveil plans for new stadium|accessdate=January 15, 2008|date=December 13, 2006|publisher=ESPN.com}} A pair of nearly {{convert|300|ft|m|0|abbr=on|adj=on}}-tall arches spans the length of the [[stadium]] [[dome]], anchored to the ground at each end. The new stadium also includes "more than 3,000 Sony LCD displays throughout the luxury suites, concourses, concession areas and more, offering fans viewing options that extend beyond the action on the field".{{cite web |url=http://www.sonyinsider.com/2009/04/20/dallas-cowboys-new-stadium-chock-full-of-sony-hd/|title=Dallas Cowboys New Stadium Chock Full Of Sony HD|publisher=Sony Insider|date=April 20, 2009|accessdate=February 6, 2011}} It also houses a center-hung [[Mitsubishi]] video display board that was the largest [[high-definition television]] screen in the world at the time of their installation.{{cite web|last=Chase |first=Chris |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/Guinness-World-Records-to-bw-1520012443.html?x=0&.v=1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003120755/http://finance.yahoo.com/news/Guinness-World-Records-to-bw-1520012443.html?x=0&.v=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 3, 2009 |title=Guinness World Records to Recognize Dallas Cowboys and Mitsubishi Electric Diamond Vision for World's Largest Video Display |publisher=finance.yahoo.com |date=September 28, 2009 |accessdate=October 8, 2009 }} It has since been surpassed in size by the [[Panasonic]] "Big Hoss" video board (218 feet (66 m) wide and 94.6 feet (28.8 m) tall) at [[Texas Motor Speedway]].{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/texas-motor-speedway-unveils-largest-hd-screen-22979104|title=Sports News|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=10 December 2015}} Glass doors, allowing each end zone to be opened, were designed and constructed by Dallas-based Haley-Greer glass systems. The retractable roof was designed by structural engineering firm [[Walter P Moore Engineers and Consultants|Walter P Moore]] and the systems were implemented by mechanization consultants [[Uni-Systems]]. The [[Electrification (rail)|electrification]] of Cowboys Stadium's [[retractable roof]] was developed by VAHLE, Inc.{{cite web |url=http://www.vahleinc.com/stadium-systems.html|title=Stadium Systems & Technology : Vahle Electrification|publisher=Vahleinc.com|accessdate=May 28, 2012}} These [[Kinetic Architecture]] fundamentals will be employed in order to create quick conversions of the facility to accommodate a variety of events. When the design was officially unveiled on December 12, 2006, it showed that, from inside the stadium, the roof (membrane installed by K Post Company of Dallas){{cite news |url=http://dallas.bizjournals.com/dallas/stories/2009/03/09/focus5.html|accessdate=April 16, 2009|title=Snapshot: Key contracts awarded for Dallas Cowboys stadium|publisher=Dallas Business Journal|date=March 6, 2009}} will look very similar to the Texas Stadium roof, with its trademark hole. However, it can be covered by the retractable roof panel to protect against the elements. The football turf field was built by Hellas Construction. They developed a special SoftTop Convertible Turf System that has 26 interchangeable panels to allow the stadium to host a variety of events from concerts, dirt bike and monster truck rallies to college football, basketball, and soccer games.{{cite news | author =Hellas Construction | title =New Dallas Cowboys Stadium Selects SoftTop Synthetic Turf System from Hellas Construction | quote =Cowboys will be the first NFL team to use removable roll-top turf with three field capabilities | newspaper =www.prweb.com | date =December 3, 2008 | pages =1 | url =http://www.prweb.com/releases/2008/12/prweb1645154.htm| accessdate = }} A Dallas Cowboys Hall of Fame is planned for the Hall of Fame level. The drawings also include a site for a large sculpture northeast of the stadium, close to Randol Mill Road. Mayor Robert Cluck claimed to use eminent domain as a last resort but most of the properties refused to sell to the city, indicating that the incentive program was not adequate according to Glenn Sodd, an attorney representing some home owners in the area. Attorney Bob Cohen, who is representing some of the property owners, said the city gave many of his clients little incentive to sell. He said he represents the owners of some rental properties who were counting on that monthly revenue for their retirement and said most homeowners cannot afford to re-build or buy in that area with the incentive package.''Dallas Morning News'': [https://archive.is/20130911153708/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/100205dnmetstadium.27f8919.html Arlington turning to eminent domain for stadium land]. {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} It is claimed that the stadium uses more electricity than the whole country of [[Liberia]].{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2013/08/29/lets-power-africa/ |title=Let's Power Africa |publisher=Foreign Policy |date=2013-08-29 |accessdate=2017-03-27}} ==Timeline== {{multiple issues|section=yes| {{Prose|section|date=April 2018}} {{Cleanup tense|section|date=April 2018}} }} [[File:Cowboys stadium panning.ogv|thumb|300px|Video of inside the stadium]] *1994: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones says he wants to expand the 65,000-seat [[Texas Stadium]] by up to 40,000 seats, add retractable roof panels and install a climate-control system to make the stadium a year-round venue for sporting events, including the [[Super Bowl]], concerts, and conventions. *1997–2000: The Cowboys hold preliminary talks with Arlington officials about building a stadium there. The team also publicly discusses a $260 million plan to upgrade Texas Stadium. In 2000, the Cowboys compile a list of potential stadium sites, which include [[Grapevine, Texas|Grapevine]], [[Coppell, Texas|Coppell]], and Arlington. The team continues negotiating with [[Irving, Texas|Irving]] to renovate Texas Stadium. *2001: Jones says Arlington is a leading contender for a $500 million stadium. The primary site considered is the {{convert|2000|acre|abbr=on}} Lakes of Arlington tract on Farm Road 157. Other cities in the running include Grapevine and [[Grand Prairie, Texas|Grand Prairie]]. In October, Jones discusses the new stadium with the mayors of Arlington, Irving, Grapevine, and Dallas. *2003: The Cowboys ask the Irving City Council to extend their lease at Texas Stadium, which expires at the end of the 2008 season, on a year-to-year basis. They narrow their search to sites in [[Las Colinas]] and Dallas, and state legislators file bills that would allow Dallas County to increase its hotel occupancy and car rental taxes to pay for a new stadium. *2004: In April, the Cowboys announce plans to build a $650 million stadium at [[Fair Park]] in Dallas. The deal requires $425 million in public financing from a 3% hotel-occupancy tax and a 6% car-rental tax. The deal falls apart in June when [[Dallas County, Texas|Dallas County]] commissioners say they cannot justify asking voters to approve the team's request for $425  million in public funding. In July, the Cowboys and Arlington announce they are negotiating to locate the stadium near [[Globe Life Park]] (then Ameriquest Field). In August, the Arlington City Council agrees unanimously to put before voters a tax increase that would fund the city's $325 million portion of the project. Voters approve the tax increase on November 2. *2005: Arlington and the Cowboys choose the site south of Randol Mill Road and east of Collins Street for the new stadium. The city begins notifying residents and property owners of its plans to acquire their property. The Cowboys hire the HKS architectural firm to design the stadium. Early blueprints show 414 luxury suites and a two-panel retractable roof. The city completes its sale of $297.9  million in bonds to pay for its portion of the construction. Demolition of houses begins November 1. *January 2006: The Cowboys hired Oklahoma-based [[Manhattan Construction Company|Manhattan Construction]] as the general contractor for the stadium and the city completes its land purchases, although it still faces a number of lawsuits over land acquisition. Later that month, Tarrant County work crews begin demolition of more than 150 Arlington residences and small business structures to make room for the stadium.{{cite web|title=Demolition Started for Cowboys Stadium |url=http://www.acppubs.com/article/CA6303364.html |publisher=Associated Construction Publications |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090529032135/http://www.acppubs.com/article/CA6303364.html |archivedate=May 29, 2009 }} *March 2006: Alliance announced between Manhattan Construction and two general contractors, Rayco Construction of Grand Prairie and 3i Construction of Dallas, to manage the stadium's construction.{{cite web|title=Alliance Announced |url=http://www.acppubs.com/article/CA6311619.html |publisher=Associated Construction Publications |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090529021425/http://www.acppubs.com/article/CA6311619.html |archivedate=May 29, 2009 }} *April 2006: Excavation begins by Mario Sinacola and Sons Excavating. By August, they had moved over 1.4 million cubic yards of earth, shaping a {{convert|13|to|14|acre|adj=on}} stadium bowl an average of {{convert|54|ft|m|0}} deep.{{cite web|title=All Up From Here |url=http://www.acppubs.com/article/CA6379243.html |publisher=Associated Construction Publications |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090529033024/http://www.acppubs.com/article/CA6379243.html |archivedate=May 29, 2009 }} *August 2006: Two construction cranes are raised on the site. *October 2006: The grass amphitheater on Randol Mill Road is leveled to make way for the extension of Baird Farm Road. *December 2006: The stadium's structure begins to go up and on December 12, Jerry Jones unveils the in-depth plans and designs of the stadium to the public. *January 2007: A construction worker is injured in a {{convert|20|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} fall.{{cite news|title=Construction Worker Remains Hospitalized |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/cowboysstadium/stories/013007dnmetstadium.35388655.html |newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125230808/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/cowboysstadium/stories/013007dnmetstadium.35388655.html |archivedate=January 25, 2010 }} *February 2007: Masonry work begins. *March 2007: Heldenfels Enterprises awarded the contract to manufacture and erect the pre-cast/pre-stressed concrete structural components and placement of them begins in April.{{cite web|title=Heldenfels Awarded Contract |url=http://www.acppubs.com/article/CA6423000.html |publisher=Associated Construction Publications |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090529024949/http://www.acppubs.com/article/CA6423000.html |archivedate=May 29, 2009 }} *June 2007: Work on the retractable roof, designed by Uni-Systems, starts. *July 2007: Exterior facade and enclosure work began. *October 2007: First steel arch is completed. [[File:Armed Forces Color Guard at Super Bowl XLV 1.jpg|thumb|right|Armed Forces Color Guard at Super Bowl XLV; then Cowboys Stadium]] *February 2008: Second steel arch is completed. *June 2008: Jones commissions the world's largest 1080p HDTV,{{cite web |title=Dallas Slideshows – Cowboys Unveil World's Largest HDTV|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/slideshow/view/13365766|publisher=Village Voice Media}} to hang above field. *June 2008: An electrician is [[electric shock|electrocuted]] while working on the stadium. Two days before, three people were injured while assembling a crane. *2009: The stadium is scheduled for 'substantial completion' in June. The artificial-turf field was brought into the stadium in July. The Cowboys played their first pre-season home game on August 21 and their first regular-season home game on Sunday, September 20. *May 13, 2009: Jerry Jones announced the official name of the new venue as Cowboys Stadium. *June 6, 2009: The first event is held at the stadium with country concert showcasing Lee Ann Womack, Blake Shelton, Reba McEntire, and George Strait *February 6, 2011: The 2010 NFL Season Super Bowl was hosted at the Cowboys Stadium, which saw the Green Bay Packers defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers in [[Super Bowl XLV]]. * July 25, 2013: Jerry Jones announced that the official name of the venue was changed to AT&T Stadium as part of a naming rights deal. *April 5–7, 2014: The stadium is home for the Final Four of the [[2014 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]]. * January 12, 2015: Served as host of the [[2015 College Football Playoff National Championship|first Championship game]] in the [[College Football Playoff]] era. [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]] defeated [[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon]], 42-20. * April 19, 2015: Served as host of the 50th Annual Academy of Country Music Awards hosted by Blake Shelton and Luke Bryan. * April 3, 2016: Served as the host of [[WWE]]'s [[WrestleMania 32]]. * September 26, 2016: The Stadium Club opened which was the first public five days a week restaurant and bar located within the AT&T Stadium.http://www.dallascowboys.com/news/2016/09/23/grand-opening-new-stadium-club-restaurant-set-monday-sept-26 ===Opening=== *May 27, 2009: Completed and opened to the public. Ribbon cutting ceremony includes Cowboys players (including [[Rayfield Wright]], [[Troy Aikman]], [[Emmitt Smith]], [[Michael Irvin]], [[Daryl Johnston]], [[Preston Pearson]], and [[Chad Hennings]]), North Texas mayors and various media personalities. *June 6, 2009: Country music star [[George Strait]] along with [[Reba McEntire]] headlined the first event in the new stadium.{{cite news|url=http://cbs11tv.com/local/george.strait.cowboys.2.937036.html |title=George Strait to Headline Debut of Cowboys Stadium |publisher=CBS 11 News/AP |date=February 17, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090222001133/http://cbs11tv.com/local/george.strait.cowboys.2.937036.html |archivedate=February 22, 2009 }} Opening acts included [[Blake Shelton]] and [[Lee Ann Womack]]. *July 19, 2009: The first sporting event is held in Cowboys Stadium. [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]] won in the Gold Cup Quarterfinal game versus [[Guadeloupe national football team|Guadeloupe]], with the first goal scored in stadium history during the 2nd minute by [[Celso Borges]]. That match was immediately followed by a sold out match between Mexico and Haiti, with 82,252 in attendance. *July 26, 2009: The final match of the [[2009 World Football Challenge]] is held between [[Chelsea F.C.]] and [[Club America]]. The [[London]] club won the match 2-0 in front of 57,229. The event was the second sporting event held in the new stadium, but was notable as the first event held during a severe thunderstorm.{{cite web |url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2009/07/Issue-215/The-Back-Of-The-Book/CONCACAF-Gold-Cup-Attendance-Down-Slightly-From-07.aspx?hl=Columbus%20Crew&sc=0|title=CONCACAF Gold Cup Attendance Down Slightly From '07|publisher=SportsBusiness Daily|date=July 28, 2009|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} *August 20, 2009: [[Jody Dean]], a member of the Texas Radio Hall of Fame and KLUV-FM (98.7) talk show host, will be Cowboys Stadium's public address announcer. Dean replaces [[KTCK (AM)|KTCK 1310 AM "The Ticket"'s]] [[George Dunham]], the longtime voice of Texas Stadium.{{cite news |title=Dean Named PA Announcer for Cowboys Stadium|first=Todd|last=Archer|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/cowboys/stories/082109dnspocowshort.30e0a5d.html|newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|date=August 20, 2009|accessdate=August 20, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091028133617/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/cowboys/stories/082109dnspocowshort.30e0a5d.html|archivedate=October 28, 2009|deadurl=yes}} *August 21, 2009: The Cowboys played the [[Tennessee Titans]] in their first preseason home game and first American football game ever played at Cowboys Stadium. The game was nationally televised on [[NFL on Fox|FOX]] at 7 PM CDT.{{cite news |title=Titans to Host Bucs, Packers in Preseason|url=http://www.nashvillecitypaper.com/content/sports/titans-host-bucs-packers-preseason|newspaper=[[The City Paper]]|location=Nashville|date=March 31, 2009|accessdate=May 25, 2009}} Dallas won the game 30–10, with one play from scrimmage blown dead when a ball punted by Titans' rookie punter [[A. J. Trapasso]] struck the main video screen after repeatedly striking it during pregame warmups. * September 5, 2009: Brigham Young defeated Oklahoma 14-13 in the first "regular season" game played in the new stadium.{{Cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/game?gameId=292480201 |title=BYU vs. Oklahoma - Game Summary - September 5, 2009 - ESPN |website=ESPN.com |access-date=2017-12-15}} *September 20, 2009: The Cowboys played their first NFL regular season game in the new stadium, with former [[President of the United States|President]] and Texas resident [[George W. Bush]] handling the opening coin toss. The Cowboys lost to their long-time NFC East division rivals, the [[New York Giants]], 33–31 with [[Eli Manning]] leading them on a last second field goal by [[Lawrence Tynes]]. It was televised on [[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]].{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=AhmV9HU_sVbiQuFtXL_52GZDubYF?slug=ap-nflschedule&prov=ap&type=lgns |title=NFL releases full regular-season schedule |publisher=yahoo.com |date=April 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019074505/https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news |archivedate=October 19, 2011 }} This game attracted a record-breaking crowd of 105,121.{{cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d812c91b4/article/nfl-regularseasonrecord-crowd-of-105121-sees-giantscowboys|title=NFL regular-season-record crowd of 105,121 sees Giants-Cowboys|publisher=nfl.com|date=September 21, 2009|accessdate=April 19, 2015}} After the game, Manning signed the wall of the visitor's locker room with the message, "First win in the New Stadium."{{cite news|title=A Sign of Conquest, Eli Manning's Signature, Remains at Cowboys Stadium |url=http://cowboysblog.dallasnews.com/archives/2010/10/a-sign-of-conquest-eli-manning.html |newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |date=October 25, 2010 |accessdate=May 27, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129094915/http://cowboysblog.dallasnews.com/archives/2010/10/a-sign-of-conquest-eli-manning.html |archivedate=November 29, 2010 |df= }} *September 28, 2009: The Cowboys got their first home regular season win. They beat the Carolina Panthers 21–7 with 90,588 in attendance. The game was televised on [[ESPN]]'s ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' and marked a record 42nd win for the Cowboys on MNF.[http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=290928006 "Cowboys shut down Panthers"], ESPN.com, September 28, 2009. Retrieved on September 28, 2009. ==Naming== Although the stadium had yet to sell [[naming rights]], many fans started referring to the project with various nicknames such as '''Jerry World''',{{cite web |url=http://www.news10.net/sports/story.aspx?storyid=61678|title=Cowboys Hope New Home Brings NorCal Fans News10.net | Sacramento, California | Sports News|publisher=News10.net|date=June 21, 2009|accessdate=February 6, 2011}}[http://www.wfaa.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/cowboysstadium/stories/DN-stadiumscoop_27met.ART.South.Edition1.4e5f6e0.html]{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}Kreindler, Eric, [http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/sports/Hoops-Heaven-at-JerryWorld-79461267.html Hoops Heaven at JerryWorld: Crews prepare for Texas basketball game], December 16, 2009. Retrieved January 10, 2010. the "[[Death Star]]",{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/30/sports/football/30nfl.html?|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|first=Joe|last=Drape|title=For N.F.L., Lockout Would Be a Risky Strategy|date=January 29, 2011}} "The Palace in Dallas" (for which announcer Bob Costas was criticized by the Arlington mayor{{cite web|url=http://stadiumblog.dallasnews.com/archives/2009/09/costas-reference-to-the-palace.html |title=Costas reference to "the palace in Dallas" irks Arlington mayor |work=Cowboys Stadium Blog |publisher=Stadiumblog.dallasnews.com |date=September 22, 2009 |accessdate=May 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117131447/http://stadiumblog.dallasnews.com/archives/2009/09/costas-reference-to-the-palace.html |archivedate=November 17, 2011 }}), "Cowboys Cathedral",{{cite web |last=Popik|first=Barry|url=http://www.barrypopik.com/index.php/new_york_city/entry/cowboys_cathedral_or_cathedral_of_football_dallas_cowboys_stadium_in_arling/|title=The Big Apple: Cowboys Cathedral or Cathedral of Football (Dallas Cowboys Stadium in Arlington)|publisher=Barrypopik.com|date=August 7, 2009|accessdate=May 28, 2012}} "Jerrassic Park" and others.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/columns/story?columnist=mosley_matt&id=2879314|accessdate=January 15, 2008|title=Indy, Arizona had no chance|publisher=ESPN.com|author=Mosley, Matt|date=May 22, 2007}} There was also a petition by some fans to have the stadium named after longtime Cowboys' coach [[Tom Landry]]. On May 13, 2009, Jerry Jones announced the official name as Cowboys Stadium.{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4164418|title=New Dallas Cowboys stadium to be called Cowboys Stadium|publisher=ESPN|date=May 13, 2009|accessdate=May 13, 2009}} On July 25, 2013, Jerry Jones announced that the Dallas Cowboys had agreed to grant naming rights to AT&T. The name change from Cowboys Stadium to AT&T Stadium took effect immediately.{{cite news|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000220798/article/cowboys-stadium-is-now-called-att-stadium|title=Cowboys Stadium now called AT&T Stadium after deal|publisher=NFL.com|date=July 25, 2013|accessdate=July 25, 2013}} The sponsorship deal was reported to be worth about $17–19 million per year.{{cite web|title=Report: AT&T naming rights for Dallas Cowboys' stadium $17-19M a year|author=Staff reports|publisher=[[Dallas Morning News]]|date=July 25, 2013|accessdate=July 26, 2013|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sports/dallas-cowboys/headlines/20130725-att-stadium-the-new-name-for-arlington-s-cowboys-stadium.ece}} [[Facility Solutions Group]] installed the "AT&T Stadium" letters on the top of the stadium. Signage includes two sets of letters {{convert|43|ft|m}} tall stretching {{convert|385|ft|m}}. The letters are made of lightweight components and aluminum and are insulated and heated to melt ice and snow.{{cite news|last1=Nagy|first1=Monica|title=Crews finish mounting massive 'AT&T' letters on Cowboys' stadium|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2014/03/07/5631038/crews-finish-mounting-massive.html?rh=1|accessdate=22 June 2014|publisher=Fort Worth Star-Telegram|date=3 March 2014}} This is AT&T's fourth major sports venue where it holds the naming rights. The others are [[AT&T Park]] in [[San Francisco]], [[AT&T Center]] in [[San Antonio]], and [[Jones AT&T Stadium]] in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]]. ==Video board== [[Guinness World Records]] was on hand at the September 28, 2009 game against the Carolina Panthers to award certificates to the Chairman of [[Mitsubishi Electric]] and Dallas Cowboys owner [[Jerry Jones]] for the World's Largest [[High-definition video|High-Definition Video Display]]. For basketball events played in Cowboys Stadium, such as the [[2010 NBA All-Star Game]], the video board is actually larger than the court. It has since been surpassed in size by the video boards at [[TIAA Bank Field]]. During the debut preseason game of Cowboys Stadium on August 21, 2009, a punt by Tennessee Titans punter [[A. J. Trapasso]] hit the 175 feet (53.34 m) wide screen above the field. The punt deflected backwards and was ruled in-play until Titans coach [[Jeff Fisher]] informed the officials that the punt struck the [[scoreboard]]. By rule, the down was replayed. Jerry Jones believes that Trapasso was trying to hit the scoreboard, saying, "If you look at how you [[Punt (gridiron football)|punt]] the [[American football ball|football]], unless you're trying to hit the scoreboard, you punt the ball to get downfield. You certainly want to get some hangtime, but you punt the ball to get downfield, and you sure don't punt the ball down the middle. You punt it off to the side."{{cite web |last=Chase|first=Chris|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/blog/shutdown_corner/post/Punt-hits-video-screen-at-new-Cowboys-Stadium?urn=nfl,184487|title=Punt hits video screen at new Cowboys Stadium – Shutdown Corner – NFL – Yahoo! Sports|publisher=Sports.yahoo.com|date=August 22, 2009|accessdate=August 26, 2009}} Whether the screen would affect an opposing team's punting strategy has been debated. For teams with strategies centered on maximizing hang-time, physicist Christopher Moore of [[Longwood University]] has shown via computer simulation that well-kicked punts have the potential to hit the screen no matter the field position.{{cite news|last=Archer |first=Todd |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/cowboys/stories/082509dnspocowlede.3ff1433.html |title=The Cowboys Stadium digital board is a hot topic |newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |date=August 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115043318/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/cowboys/stories/082509dnspocowlede.3ff1433.html |archivedate=January 15, 2010 }} Trapasso disputed Jones' suggestion that he was intentionally trying to hit the board, and other NFL punters have suggested that the board may pose a problem for longer hang-time punts. The screen was retrofitted with 16 custom winches using 11,000 feet (3.35 km) of {{convert|1.5|in|cm}} domestic galvanized wire rope from [[Tway Lifting Products]] to accomplish the safe, efficient transport of the video board in time to make room for [[U2|U2's]] massive set during their [[360° Tour]], and was moved back down after the concert.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} The video board is also the primary attachment point for up to 370,000 lb (168 metric tons) of concert and theatrical rigging.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} On August 24, 2013, Cowboys punter [[Chris Jones (punter)|Chris Jones]] became the second player to hit the scoreboard. He conceded a touchdown on the re-kick.{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/videos/cincinnati-bengals/0ap2000000233700/Can-t-Miss-Play-Punt-hits-Cowboys-scoreboard|title=Pre Wk 3 Can't-Miss Play: Cincinnati Bengals receiver Brandon Tate returns re-punt for touchdown|work=NFL.com|accessdate=10 December 2015}} ==Major events== ===NBA All-Star Weekend=== On February 14, 2010, the stadium hosted the [[2010 NBA All-Star Game]]. With an announced crowd of 108,713, the game became the highest-attended basketball game in history, setting a new Guinness World Record. The East squad prevailed with a 141–139 victory over the West.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/history/allstar/2010-all-star-game-recap/index.html|title=2010 All-Star Game recap|work=[[National Basketball Association]]|date=2011-12-05|accessdate=2012-11-03}} ===NFL=== [[File:Cowboys Stadium field.jpg|thumb|right|Cowboys playing at the stadium]] *On January 3, 2010, the Cowboys defeated the Philadelphia Eagles in a 24–0 shutout to win the NFC East division title and complete the first ever back-to-back shutouts in franchise history.{{cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/teams/schedule?team=DAL&season=2009&seasonType=REG|title=Dallas Cowboys Schedule at|publisher=Nfl.com|accessdate=February 6, 2011}} *On January 9, 2010, the Cowboys hosted their first playoff game in the new stadium, again playing the Eagles. Dallas won 34–14, breaking their infamous [[List of NFL franchise post-season droughts#Active playoff game victory droughts|13-year playoff win drought]]. *On February 6, 2011, the stadium hosted [[Super Bowl XLV]] in which the [[2010 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] defeated the [[2010 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]], 31–25. Others bidding for the game's location were the [[University of Phoenix Stadium]] in [[Glendale, Arizona]] and [[Lucas Oil Stadium]] in [[Indianapolis|Indianapolis, Indiana]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dallascowboys.com/news.cfm?id=B4F2408B-E56F-5F4B-DAB3644206D02A55|title=At Long Last, Super Bowl Coming To North Texas|date=May 22, 2007|accessdate=January 15, 2008|first=Mickey|last=Spagnola|publisher=DallasCowboys.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230190909/http://www.dallascowboys.com/news.cfm?id=B4F2408B-E56F-5F4B-DAB3644206D02A55|archivedate=December 30, 2007}} The Cowboys attempted to increase its capacity to 105,000 seats in hopes of setting the record for attendance at a Super Bowl. In a last-minute rush to add seats during one of the area's notorious ice storms, 7 construction workers were injured by ice sliding off of the stadium roof.{{cite news |last=Williams|first=Charean|title=Super Bowl Bound to Return, But When?|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2012/01/29/3696529/super-bowl-bound-to-return-but.html|accessdate=May 21, 2012|newspaper=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]|date=January 29, 2012}} Hours before kickoff, over 1,200 seats were blocked off in the interest of safety; according to a police officer in the affected area, the seats hadn't been finished in time for the fire marshal to inspect them.Sickles, Jason. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=ys-angryfans020611 Fans denied access to seats for Super Bowl]. [[Yahoo! Sports]], 2011-02-06. Approximately 800 people were given other seats inside the stadium, thus costing the NFL any chance of setting the Super Bowl attendance record (the final figure of 103,219 came 766 short of the record set in [[Super Bowl XIV]]). However, about 400 people were unable to be seated and were given a letter from the NFL that could be exchanged for three times the face value of the ticket. Those people were also given the option to either watch on a TV in one of the stadium's lounges, where they would be unable to see the field in person, or watch on screens outside the stadium. The NFL also announced that those 400 people would receive free tickets to the [[Super Bowl XLVI|next year's Super Bowl]]. On February 9, 2011, the first lawsuit was filed against the NFL and Jerry Jones.{{cite web |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/602966-super-bowl-seating-lawsuit-why-jerry-jones-must-pay-the-displaced-fans|title=Super Bowl Seating Lawsuit: Why Jerry Jones Must Pay the Displaced Fans|date=February 9, 2011|accessdate=February 9, 2011}} ===College football=== ====College Football Playoff National Championship==== {{Main|College Football Playoff National Championship}} *January 12, 2015: The (4) [[2014 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State Buckeyes]] defeated the (2) [[2014 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon Ducks]] 42–20, before a crowd of 85,689 in the inaugural [[2015 College Football Playoff National Championship]]. ====Big 12 Championship Game==== {{See also|Big 12 Championship Game}} [[File:University of Texas marching band Big 12 Championship game.jpg|thumb|220px|right|University of Texas marching band during the Big 12 Championship game]] AT&T Stadium, then known as Cowboys Stadium, was the site of the 2009 and 2010 [[Big 12 Championship Game]]s, the last two held prior to the [[2010–13 Big 12 Conference realignment]]. On December 5, 2009, the [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorns]] defeated the [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska Cornhuskers]] 13–12 in the [[2009 Big 12 Championship Game]], the first to be held in the stadium with attendance announced at 76,211.{{cite web |authors=Cowboy Stadium, ARLINGTON, TX |url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/boxscore?gameId=293390158|title=Texas Longhorns vs. Nebraska Cornhuskers – Box Score – December 05, 2009 – ESPN|publisher=Scores.espn.go.com|date=December 5, 2009|accessdate=February 6, 2011}} The following year, on December 4, 2010, the [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]] and Nebraska Cornhuskers rekindled [[Nebraska–Oklahoma football rivalry|their rivalry]] as the Sooners won 23–20 in the [[2010 Big 12 Championship Game|final Big 12 Championship game]] to date and will return starting with the 2017 season. The stadium was scheduled to host the games through the 2013 season, but the realignment of the [[Big 12 Conference]] to 10 teams meant they were not allowed to host a championship game because of NCAA rules requiring conferences to have at least 12 teams divided into two divisions in order to stage a championship game.{{cite web|url=http://www.big12sports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=106116&SPID=13135&DB_OEM_ID=10410&ATCLID=1521887 |title=Big 12 Conference Concludes Spring Meetings; Future Championship Sites Approved For Football, Basketball |publisher=Big12sports.com: The Big 12 Conference Official Athletic Site |date=May 24, 2007 |accessdate=June 21, 2010}}{{cite news |title=Big 12 football: Why a conference championship game is the easiest fix for Big 12's woes |url=http://newsok.com/big-12-football-why-a-conference-championship-game-is-the-easiest-fix-for-big-12s-woes/article/5375846 |author=Tramel, Berry |date=December 13, 2014 |newspaper=[[The Oklahoman]] |accessdate=January 6, 2015}} ====Cotton Bowl Classic==== {{Main|Cotton Bowl Classic}} *January 2, 2010: In the first bowl game played at the stadium, the [[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss Rebels]] defeated the [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma State Cowboys]], 21–7 in the [[2010 Cotton Bowl Classic|74th installment of the AT&T Cotton Bowl Classic]]. Attendance was 77,928 and was the third largest attendance of any preceding Cotton Bowl game. With Oklahoma State having played in the Cotton Bowl, all [[Big 12 South]] Teams have played at least one game in the Cowboys Stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.okstate.com/sports/m-footbl/stats/2009-2010/fb010210.html|title=Oklahoma State Official Athletic Site – Football|publisher=Okstate.com|date=January 2, 2010|accessdate=February 6, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612161438/http://www.okstate.com/sports/m-footbl/stats/2009-2010/fb010210.html|archive-date=2011-06-12|dead-url=yes|df=}} *January 7, 2011: In the [[2011 Cotton Bowl Classic|75th installment of the AT&T Cotton Bowl Classic]], the [[LSU Tigers football|LSU Tigers]] by a score of 41–24 defeated the [[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M Aggies]] with an outstanding attendance of 83,514 making it the second largest attendance in Cotton Bowl history. LSU finished with an 11–2 record and Texas A&M finished 9–4 making it their 49th meeting all time. *January 6, 2012: The [[Arkansas Razorbacks football|Arkansas Razorbacks]] defeated [[Kansas State Wildcats football|Kansas State Wildcats,]] 29–16. Attendance was 80,956, currently the third-highest attendance in Cotton Bowl history. During the game, Arkansas receiver [[Joe Adams (wide receiver)|Joe Adams]] returned a punt 51 yards for a touchdown, which was the first punt return for a touchdown in the Cotton Bowl since former Arkansas Razorback [[Lance Alworth]] returned a punt 49 yards for a touchdown in a 7-6 loss to [[Duke]] in 1961. The win also propelled the Razorbacks to a #5 ranking in the final AP poll and gave them their first 11-win season since joining the [[Southeastern Conference]] in 1991. Kansas State ended the season with a 10-3 record and ranked #15 in the final AP poll. *January 4, 2013: The (10) [[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M Aggies]] defeated the (12) [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]] 41–13 to finish the season with an 11–2 record. [[Johnny Manziel]] rushed for 229 yards (on just 17 carries) during the game, a Cotton Bowl record and national bowl record for a quarterback, rushing for two touchdowns and throwing for two more. Manziel totaled 516 total yards also a Cotton Bowl Classic record. Though the halftime score was 14–13 Texas A&M, the Aggies went on to score 27 unanswered second half points to win the game. The game's attendance of 87,025 is the second highest in Cotton Bowl Classic history, behind the 2009 game between Mississippi-Texas Tech at 88,175. *January 3, 2014: The (9) [[Missouri Tigers football|Missouri Tigers]] defeated the (13) [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma State Cowboys]] 41–31 in front of an attendance of 72,690. *January 1, 2015: The (7) [[Michigan State Spartans football|Michigan State Spartans]] rallied from a 20-point deficit to defeat the (4) [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor Bears]] 42–41 in front of an attendance of 71,464. This was the first Cotton Bowl Classic game to be featured as one of the "New Year's Six" bowls of the [[College Football Playoff]]. *January 2, 2016: The (8) [[2016 Wisconsin Badgers football team|Wisconsin Badgers]] defeated the (15) [[2016 Western Michigan Broncos football team|Western Michigan Broncos]] in front of 59,615. *December 29, 2017: The (5) [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State Buckeyes]] defeated the (8) [[University of Southern California Trojans|USC Trojans]] by a score of 24-7 in front of 67,510. ====Advocare Classic==== {{Main|Advocare Classic}} *September 5, 2009: The (20) [[2009 BYU Cougars football team|Brigham Young University Cougars]] and (3) [[2009 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma Sooners]] played the first college football game in the new stadium, with the Cougars upsetting the Sooners, 14–13, in front of 75,437 spectators. So BYU holds the distinction of being the first college team to win a game in the stadium, and the team to win the first (non-preseason) game in the stadium.{{cite web|author= |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=AhmV9HU_sVbiQuFtXL_52GZDubYF?slug=ap-nflschedule&prov=ap&type=lgns |title=NFL releases full regular-season schedule – NFL – Yahoo! Sports |publisher=Sports.yahoo.com |date=April 26, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505200332/https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news |archivedate=May 5, 2009 }} *September 4, 2010: (6) [[2010 TCU Horned Frogs football team|TCU]] defeated (24) [[2010 Oregon State Beavers football team|Oregon State]] 30–21, before a crowd of 46,138, in a [[2010 NCAA Division I FBS football season|season]]-opening encounter between [[2010 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings|ranked]] teams.{{cite web|url=http://gofrogs.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/stats/2010-2011/osu-tcu.html |title=Scoring Summary (Final) : 2010 TCU Football Statistics |website=Gofrogs.cstv.com |accessdate=2017-03-27}} *September 3, 2011: (4) [[2011 LSU Tigers football team|LSU]] defeated (3) [[2011 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] 40–27, before a crowd of 87,711 in the third installment of the Cowboys Classic. *September 1, 2012: Defending 2011 champion (2) [[2012 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]] defeated (8) [[2012 Michigan Wolverines football team|Michigan]] 41-14, before a crowd of 90,413 in the fourth installment of the Cowboys Classic. * August 31, 2013: (12) [[2013 LSU Tigers football team|LSU]] defeated (20) [[2013 TCU Horned Frogs football team|TCU]] 37-27, before a crowd of 80,230 in the fifth installment of the Cowboys Classic. * August 30, 2014: Defending 2013 champion (1) [[2014 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] defeated unranked [[2014 Oklahoma State Cowboys football team|Oklahoma State]] 37-31, before a crowd of 61,521 in the sixth installment of the Cowboys Classic. ====Southwest Classic==== {{Main|Arkansas–Texas A&M football rivalry}} The [[Arkansas Razorbacks]] vs. [[Texas A&M Aggies]] football rivalry, which began in 1903, was renewed in 2009 as the Southwest Classic, and was played at Cowboys Stadium from 2009 through 2011. In 2012, Texas A&M joined Arkansas in the [[Southeastern Conference]], and the series reverted to the schools' home fields, [[Kyle Field]] in [[College Station, Texas]] for the 2012 game and [[Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium]] in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]] in 2013. The Southwest Classic returned to AT&T Stadium in 2014 and will remain there through at least 2020. *October 3, 2009: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones watched his alma mater, the Arkansas Razorbacks, defeat the Texas A&M Aggies 47–19 in the first of ten games called the ''Southwest Classic'' to be played at the stadium.[http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292760008] ESPN.com, October 3, 2009. Retrieved on October 3, 2009. *October 9, 2010: The Arkansas Razorbacks jumped out to an early 21-7 lead, and held on to defeat the Texas A&M Aggies, 24-17.[http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=302820245] ESPN.com, October 9, 2010. *October 1, 2011: The Arkansas Razorbacks rallied from an 18-point halftime deficit to defeat the Texas A&M Aggies 41-38. *September 27, 2014: The Texas A&M Aggies rallied from a deficit to force overtime and then scored the only TD for the 35-28 win to defeat the Arkansas Razorbacks. *September 26, 2015: Texas A&M rallied from a fourth quarter deficit for the second straight year versus Arkansas, beating the Razorbacks 28-21 in OT. *September 24, 2016: After being tied at halftime, the Aggies dominated the second half to defeat the Razorbacks 45–24. ====Texas Farm Bureau Insurance Shootout==== {{Main|Baylor–Texas Tech football rivalry}} In 2009, the Big 12 Conference game between the [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor Bears]] and [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech Red Raiders]] was held at Cowboys Stadium, the first time in the series the match-up was held on a neutral site. The game was the highest attended in the series' history, with 71,964 in attendance.{{cite web |authors=Cowboy Stadium, ARLINGTON, TX|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/boxscore?gameId=293320239|title=Texas Tech Red Raiders vs. Baylor Bears – Box Score – November 28, 2009 – ESPN|publisher=Scores.espn.go.com|date=November 28, 2009|accessdate=February 6, 2011}} After the 2010 game was held at the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]] in [[Fair Park|Fair Park, Dallas]] during the [[State Fair of Texas]], the series returned to AT&T Stadium for the 2011 and 2012 games. The series' neutral site contract at AT&T Stadium could continue until 2014.{{cite news |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sports/college-sports/texas-tech-red-raiders/20110223-baylor-texas-tech-to-play-football-in-cowboys-stadium-in-2011.ece|title=Baylor, Texas Tech to play football in Cowboys Stadium in 2011 | Texas Tech Red Raiders News - Sports News for Dallas, Texas - SportsDayDFW|newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|date=February 23, 2011|accessdate=May 28, 2012}} ===Basketball=== [[File:Cowboys Stadium configured for basketball.jpg|thumb|right|The stadium being set up for Texas vs. North Carolina game]] *December 19, 2009: In the first college basketball game at the stadium, before a crowd of 38,052, the Texas Longhorns defeated the defending national champion North Carolina Tar Heels, 103–90.{{cite web |url=http://www.texassports.com/sports/m-baskbl/stats/2009-2010/dec19.html|title=Official website of University of Texas Athletics – Texas Longhorns – Men's Basketball|publisher=TexasSports.com|accessdate=February 6, 2011}} *March 2013: 2013 NCAA Tournament South Regional featuring 3 games with the winner of the third going to the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Men's Final Four]]{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/ncaab-the-dagger/south-regional-cowboys-stadium-features-giant-tv-screen-165528323--ncaab.html|title=South regional at Cowboys Stadium features a giant TV screen — and, oh yeah, a basketball court|date=28 March 2013|work=Yahoo Sports|accessdate=10 December 2015}} *2014: [[2014 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2014 NCAA Men's Final Four]][https://www.att.com/gen/press-room?pid=25318]{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ===Soccer=== {{Main|Soccer matches at AT&T Stadium}} *July 19, 2009 – Cowboys Stadium hosted two matches in the quarterfinal round of the [[2009 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. Costa Rica defeated Guadeloupe, 5–1. Mexico shut out Haiti, 4–0 in front of 85,000 fans. *July 17, 2010 – On July 17, 2010, two of the top professional soccer clubs in Mexico – [[Club America]] and [[San Luis F.C.]] – met in a friendly at Cowboys Stadium. Club America made its second appearance at Cowboys Stadium. In 2009, Club America played [[Chelsea FC]] in the [[World Football Challenge]] in front of 57,229 fans at Cowboys Stadium.{{cite web|url=http://stadium.dallascowboys.com/events/eventDetail.cfm?id=41BD83D9-F6FB-7CD8-B440E057A148EAD1 |title=Events |publisher=Stadium.dallascowboys.com |accessdate=February 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708222643/http://stadium.dallascowboys.com/events/eventDetail.cfm?id=41BD83D9-F6FB-7CD8-B440E057A148EAD1 |archivedate=July 8, 2011 }} *June 5, 2011 – Cowboys Stadium hosted the opening matches of the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. Costa Rica defeated Cuba 5–0 in the opener, while Mexico defeated El Salvador 5–0 in the nightcap in front of 80,108 fans. *August 6, 2011 – [[2011 World Football Challenge]]; [[Club America]] vs [[FC Barcelona]]; score 2-0 in front of 60,087 fans. *June 3, 2012 – Cowboys Stadium hosted a soccer match in which [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] played against 5-time world cup champions [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]]. Mexico defeated Brazil 2–0 with goals from [[Giovani dos Santos]] and [[Javier Hernández]]. *July 24, 2013 – Cowboys Stadium hosted the semifinals matches of the [[2013 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] defeated Honduras 3–1 and Panama defeated Mexico 2–1. It was the last event at the venue using the name Cowboys Stadium, and was the first appearance of the U.S. soccer team at this stadium. *July 22, 2017 [[2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]] defeated 0-2. *July 31, 2018 [[2018 International Champions Cup]]; [[FC Barcelona]] vs [[AS Roma]] Roma defeated Barcelona 4-2 ===Boxing=== The stadium has hosted three world championship boxing fights since its opening, as the large capacity and retractable roof make it an ideal venue for boxing events throughout the year. Two of the sports biggest stars in [[Manny Pacquiao]] and [[Canelo Álvarez|Saul "Canelo" Álvarez]] have headlined championship bouts there, with top level boxing set to return on March 16, 2019 when unbeaten champions [[Errol Spence Jr.]] and [[Mikey Garcia]] square off for the [[List of IBF world champions#Welterweight|IBF Welterweight Championship]]. *March 13, 2010 - [[Manny Pacquiao vs. Joshua Clottey|The Event]]. Before a crowd of 50,994, [[Manny Pacquiao]] recorded a unanimous decision over [[Joshua Clottey]] to retain his [[List of WBO world champions#Welterweight|WBO welterweight title]]. * November 13, 2010 – [[Manny Pacquiao vs. Antonio Margarito|The Eighth Wonder of the World]]. In front of 41,734 fans, Manny Pacquiao defeated [[Antonio Margarito]] to win the [[List of WBC world champions#Superwelterweight|WBC Super welterweight title]]. In doing so, he made history in becoming the [[Octuple champion|first fighter to win world titles in 8 different weight classes]]. * September 17, 2016 – Before a crowd of 51,420, [[Canelo Álvarez]] defeated [[Liam Smith (boxer)|Liam Smith]] by knockout in round nine to win the [[list of WBO world champions#Junior middleweight|WBO light middleweight title]]. The event broke the AT&T Stadium attendance record for boxing.{{cite web|last1=Coppinger|first1=Mike|title=Canelo Alvarez knocks out Liam Smith with punishing body shot|url=http://boxingjunkie.usatoday.com/2016/09/18/canelo-alvarez-knocks-out-liam-smith-with-punishing-body-shot/|website=USA Today|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=18 September 2016}} ===WrestleMania 32=== *AT&T Stadium hosted [[WWE]]'s [[WrestleMania 32]] on April 3, 2016. This marked the third [[WrestleMania]] to be hosted in Texas. The area also hosted activities throughout the region for the week-long celebration leading up to WrestleMania itself.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/32/att-stadium-to-host-wrestlemania-32-27013296|title=AT&T Stadium to host WrestleMania 32}} The attendance announced was 101,763 and it was said that they had broken the attendance record of the stadium. === Supercross === AT&T Stadium has hosted a round of the [[AMA Supercross Championship]] since 2010, replacing Texas Stadium which had been host since 1975.{{cite web|url=http://www.amasupercross.com/MediaGuide/SXMediaGuide_15_lores.pdf |format=PDF |title=2015 Series Guide |website=Amasupercross.com |accessdate=2017-03-27}} ===Concerts=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! width=12% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Dallas Cowboys|border=2}};|Date ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Dallas Cowboys|border=2}};|Artist ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Dallas Cowboys|border=2}};|Opening act(s) ! width=16% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Dallas Cowboys|border=2}};|Tour / Concert name ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Dallas Cowboys|border=2}};|Attendance ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Dallas Cowboys|border=2}};|Revenue ! width=20% style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Dallas Cowboys|border=2}};|Notes |- | June 6, 2009 | [[George Strait]] | [[Reba McEntire]]

Trinity won, 42–21.{{cite web|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090721006379/en/FOX-Sports-Southwest-Kicks-2009-High-School|title=FOX Sports Southwest Kicks Off 2009 High School Football Season from New Cowboys Stadium|date=July 21, 2009|accessdate=October 17, 2018|publisher=[[BusinessWire]]}}
{{cite web|url=http://highschoolfootballamerica.com/kirk-herbstreit-varsity-challenge-dallas-tx/|title=Kirk Herbstreit Varsity Challenge – Dallas, TX|first=Jeff|last=Fisher|publisher=High School Football America|date=September 7, 2009|accessdate=October 17, 2018}}
{{cite web|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/705328433/High-school-football-Bingham-finishes-strong-but-still-falls-to-Texas-powerhouse.html|title=High school football: Bingham finishes strong but still falls to Texas powerhouse|first=Dennis|last=Hall|date=September 8, 2009|accessdate=October 17, 2018|publisher=[[Deseret News]]}} * November 12, 2009 – The first Texas high school football playoff game played at Cowboys Stadium was between Bowie High School (Arlington, Texas) and Richland High School (North Richland Hills; Texas).{{cite web|url=http://stadiumblog.dallasnews.com/2009/11/four-high-school-playoff-games.html |title=Four high school playoff games scheduled for Cowboys Stadium |work=Cowboys Stadium Blog |accessdate=10 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210222934/http://stadiumblog.dallasnews.com/2009/11/four-high-school-playoff-games.html |archivedate=10 December 2015 }} * February 2010 – The [[Professional Bull Riders]] hosted the Dickies Iron Cowboy Invitational in February 2010.{{cite web|title=Professional Bull Riders Invades the Brand-New Cowboys Stadium in 2010|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/features/other-features/2009/9/professional-bull-riders-invades-the-brand-new-cowboys-stadium-in-2010-(1).aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 2010 – The first [[MDA Muscle Walk]] in the Dallas-Fort Worth area took place. This event was held annually, having returned in 2011, 2012, and 2013. That event has since moved to [[Globe Life Park in Arlington]] (formerly Rangers Ballpark) starting in 2014. [[File:MDA Muscle Walk DFW 2013.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Several participants walk at the 2013 DFW [[MDA Muscle Walk]]; then known as Cowboys Stadium.]] * February 27, 2010 – The stadium hosted its first [[Monster Jam]] event with 11 trucks. This event is now held annually, having returned in 2011 and scheduled for 2012. * June 30, 2011 – The final round of the 2011 [[U.S. Women's Open (bowling)|US Women's Open]] in bowling was played at Cowboys Stadium,{{cite web |url=http://www.bowlingdigital.com/bowl/node/9802|title=Leanne Hulsenberg triumphs in the 2011 Bowling's U.S. Women's Open|publisher=Bowlingdigital.com|accessdate=July 3, 2011}} with Leanne Hulsenberg winning. * Dec. 7-Dec. 17, 2011 – Cowboys Stadium hosted all the Texas 11-man football state championships for the first time. It was also the first time all 11-man state championships were held in one location. * February 2011 - The Professional Bull Riders hosted the Dickies Iron Cowboy Invitational in February 2011.{{cite web|title=PBR announces bracket for Dickies' Iron Cowboy Invitational presented by WinStar World Casino|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2011/2/pbr-announces-bracket-for-dickies-iron-cowboy-invitational-presented-by-winstar-world-casino.aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 2012 - The Professional Bull Riders hosted the Dickies Iron Cowboy Invitational in February 2012.{{cite web|title=Mauney crowned 2012 Dickies® Iron Cowboy|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2012/3/mauney-crowned-2012-dickies-iron-cowboy.aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 2013 - The Professional Bull Riders hosted the Dickies Iron Cowboy Invitational in February 2013.{{cite web|title=PBR returns to Cowboys Stadium|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2013/2/pbr-returns-to-arlington.aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 11, 2013 – ''American Sniper'' Chris Kyle's memorial ceremony proceeded by a 200-mile procession across Texas. * February 2013 - The Professional Bull Riders hosted the Dickies Iron Cowboy Invitational in February 2014.{{cite web|title=PBR's Iron Cowboy returns to AT&T Stadium in 2014|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2013/9/pbrs-iron-cowboy-returns-to-att-stadium-in-2014.aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 2014 - The inaugural The American Rodeo was held.{{cite web|title=About The American|url=http://www.americanrodeo.com/story/35253227/about-the-american|website=The American|publisher=www.theamericanrodeo.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * April 26, 2014 – AT&T stadium hosted the senior [[prom]] of [[South Garland High School]]. * June 27–29, 2014 – International Assembly of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] * July 6, 2014 – Semi-pro football (EFL) held its first indoor Pro-bowl game. * July 25–27, 2014 – International Assembly of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] * February 2015 - The Professional Bull Riders hosted the Choctaw Casino Resort Iron Cowboy in February 2015.{{cite web|title=First PBR Major Iron Cowboy takes place at AT&T Stadium on Feb. 28|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2015/2/iron-cowboy-preview.aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 2015 - The American Rodeo was held. * March 7, 2015 – The 2015 [[American Cup (gymnastics)|AT&T American Cup]], an [[Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique|FIG]] World Cup event, is held at the stadium. * June 20, 2015 – AT&T Stadium hosted thousands of Spartans for Reebok's Spartan Race. * February 2016 - The Professional Bull Riders hosted the Choctaw Casino Resort Iron Cowboy in February 2016.{{cite web|title=PBR's Iron Cowboy Returns to AT&T Stadium|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2015/8/pbr%E2%80%99s-iron-cowboy-returns-to-att-stadium.aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 2016 - The American Rodeo was held. * March 6, 2016 – [[Greg Laurie|Greg Laurie's]] Harvest America took place at the stadium. It is considered the largest evangelical event ever. Special guests included [[Chris Tomlin]], [[Lecrae]], [[MercyMe]], and [[Switchfoot]]. * April 3, 2016 – [[WrestleMania 32|WrestleMania]], the premier event of the [[professional wrestling]] organization [[WWE]], was held. * February 2017 - The Professional Bull Riders hosted the Choctaw Casino Resort Iron Cowboy in February 2017.{{cite web|title=Iron Cowboy Returns to AT&T Stadium in 2017|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2016/8/iron-cowboy-returns-to-att-stadium-in-2017.aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 2017 - The American Rodeo was held. * February 2018 - The Professional Bull Riders hosted the WinStar World Casino and Resort Iron Cowboy in 2018.{{cite web|title=PBR returns to AT&T Stadium for Iron Cowboy|url=http://www.pbr.com/en/news/press-releases/2017/8/pbr-returns-to-att-stadium-for-iron-cowboy.aspx|website=Professional Bull Riders|publisher=www.pbr.com|accessdate=December 17, 2017}} * February 2018 - The American Rodeo was held. * April 2018 - The Stadium hosted the [[2018 NFL Draft]] ==Concessions and merchandising== On October 20, 2008, Cowboys owner Jones and [[New York Yankees]] owner [[George Steinbrenner]] announced a joint business venture called Legends Hospitality Management LLC which would operate the concessions and merchandising sales at the new Cowboys stadium in Arlington, Texas, and at the new [[Yankee Stadium]] in the [[Bronx, New York]], along with the stadiums of the Yankees' minor league affiliates. Former [[Pizza Hut]] President Michael Rawlings will run the company from its new headquarters in [[Newark, New Jersey]]. The company was also backed by Wall Street investment firm [[Goldman Sachs]] and Dallas private equity firm [[CIC Partners LP]].[http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/102108dnbuscowboysventure.12f38f6d8.html Dallas Cowboys, New York Yankees form joint concessions venture] (''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'') {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611163734/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/102108dnbuscowboysventure.12f38f6d8.html |date=June 11, 2009 }}[http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5iSjkHX_FdX7pW5uAy-F_tVgBfT2gD93UC6C00 Cowboys, Yankees form company for new stadiums] ([[Associated Press]]) {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029053815/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5iSjkHX_FdX7pW5uAy-F_tVgBfT2gD93UC6C00 |date=October 29, 2008 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601079&sid=a84RZnI.1MW4&refer=home |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090927111547/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601079 |archivedate=2009-09-27 }} ==Stadium art program== The Jones family commissioned 18 contemporary artists to create site-specific artworks for the stadium. The stadium features paintings, sculptures, and installations by Franz Ackerman, [[Doug Aitken]], Ricci Albenda, [[Mel Bochner]], [[Daniel Buren]], [[Olafur Eliasson]], [[Teresita Fernandez]], Wayne Gonzales, Terry Haggerty, [[Trenton Doyle Hancock]], Jacqueline Humphries, Jim Isermann, Annette Lawrence, Dave Muller, Gary Simmons, and [[Lawrence Weiner]].{{cite web|url=http://stadium.dallascowboys.com/art/art_commissions.cfm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210062351/http://stadium.dallascowboys.com/art/art_commissions.cfm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 February 2010|title=Art Commissions|date=10 February 2010|publisher=}} ==Transportation== ===Parking=== The fees for premium parking at Dallas Cowboys games are estimated at $75 per game, based on season ticket holder parking charges.{{cite news |first=Gordon |last=Dickson |url=http://www.star-telegram.com/business/story/1296502.html |title=Dallas Cowboys, Texas Rangers Reach Deal on Parking Spots |newspaper=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]] |date=April 2, 2009 |archiveurl=http://cowboyszone.com/threads/fwst-dallas-cowboys-texas-rangers-reach-deal-on-parking-spots.150060/ |archivedate=April 2, 2009 }} The fees to park at major concerts and other sporting events will be nearly $40 per space at the new stadium.{{cite news|first=Bud |last=Kennedy |url=http://www.star-telegram.com/news/columnists/bud_kennedy/story/1415994.html |title=KENNEDY: $40 for Cowboys Stadium Parking? Sure Would Be Nice to Have Mass Transit... |newspaper=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]] |date=June 4, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} A shuttle operates between the [[T&P Station]] and Cowboys Stadium for all Cowboys regular season and postseason games and selected college football games,{{cite web |url=http://www.the-t.com/BusService/SpecialPrograms/tabid/247/Default.aspx |title=Special Programs |publisher=[[Fort Worth Transportation Authority|The T]] |date=January 7, 2011 |accessdate=February 6, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107125721/http://the-t.com/BusService/SpecialPrograms/tabid/247/Default.aspx |archive-date=2011-01-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} which averages approximately 900 riders per game. For special events like Super Bowl XLV parking prices can increase to as much as $990.{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Weir |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2011/01/super-bowl-parking-990/1 |title=$990 for a parking spot at the Super Bowl |work=[[USA Today]] |agency=Game On! (blog) |date=January 26, 2011 |accessdate=December 9, 2011}} ===Public transit=== The stadium was only accessible via the [[Metro Arlington Xpress]] (MAX) bus system; a {{convert|0.4|mi|km|abbr=on}} walk from the Collins and Andrews stop which connected with the [[Trinity Rail Express]] (TRE) station at [[CentrePort/DFW Airport station|CentrePort/DFW Airport]]. The bus system was an experimental program which commenced in April 2013 and was replaced by a ride-sharing service in December 2017. ==See also== {{Portal bar|Dallas-Fort Worth}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|AT&T Stadium}} * {{Official website}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title = Home of the

revision.text:
The '''Baxter Cup''' is the oldest New Zealand trophy in the sport of [[curling]]. First contested in 1884, it is thought to be the oldest still-contested New Zealand sporting trophy.<ref name ="NZC">"[http://curling.org.nz/index.php/component/content/article/87/463-naseby-council--baxter-cup Naseby Council — Baxter Cup]", New Zealand Curling. Retrieved 15 September 2017.</ref>
The trophy competition was initially held in [[Dunedin]] at the Dunedin Curling Club, but went into abeyance in 1895 after that club was dissolved. The competition was next held in [[Central Otago]] in 1900, and has been contested irregularly since that time.<ref>Since the Naseby rink is an open-air natural ice venue, bonspiels can only be held in years where the weather is cold enough.</ref> The competition is currently organised by the [[Naseby, New Zealand|Naseby]] Curling Council as a one-day [[bonspiel]].<ref name="NZC"/>
The Baxter Cup was named after David Baxter, a founding member of the Dunedin Curling Club who, who donated the trophy.<ref name="NZC"/>
The current (2017) champions are the Kyeburn Curling Club from [[Kyeburn]], who won the final in July 2017 against [[Ranfurly, New Zealand|Ranfurly]]'s Mount Ida Curling Club.<ref>"[http://www.curling.org.nz/index.php/naseby-council-and-clubs/1203-2017-baxter-cup Weather gods smile on Baxter Cup]", New Zealand Curling, 31 July 2017. Retrieved 15 September 2017.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Curling competitions in New Zealand]] [[Category: 1884 establishments in New Zealand]]
{{NewZealand-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Borleske Stadium | image = | location = 409 W Rees Ave
[[Walla Walla, Washington]] | coordinates = {{coord|46.077|-118.336|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1926. {{Years or months ago|1926}} | owner = | operator = | surface = Natural grass | construction_cost = | architect = | general_contractor = | former_names = | tenants = '''[[Walla Walla Sweets]]''' (2010–present)
'''Walla Walla Bears''' (1969, 1983)
'''Walla Walla Phillies''' (1970–1971)
'''Walla Walla Islanders''' (1972)
'''[[Walla Walla Padres]]''' (1973–1982)
'''Whitman College baseball''' (1940–present)
'''Whitman College football''' (1926–1976)
'''Walla Walla Community College football'''
'''Walla Walla High School baseball'''
'''Walla Walla HS football''' (1975–present) | seating_capacity = 2,376 | dimensions = LF: {{convert|315|ft|abbr=on}}
LC: {{convert|353|ft|abbr=on}}
CF: {{convert|410|ft|0|abbr=on}}
RC: {{convert|378|ft|abbr=on}}
RF: {{convert|333|ft|0|abbr=on}} }} '''Borleske Stadium''' is a multi-purpose outdoor athletic stadium in [[Walla Walla, Washington]]. The stadium is named for Raymond Vincent Borleske (1887–1957),{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xosRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2-MDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6846%2C662658 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=(photo) |title=Whitman coach issues orders |date=October 17, 1937 |page=5, sports}} a legendary [[Whitman College]] athlete (class of 1910) and coach. It has served as the home for a variety of professional and amateur teams in both [[American football|football]] and [[baseball]]. The stadium is part of the Borleske Stadium Complex containing Borleske Stadium, Martin Field, and Memorial Pool. It is the home venue of the Whitman College baseball team, the [[Walla Walla Sweets]] baseball team ([[West Coast League|WCL]]), and the football team of Walla Walla High School. The [[elevation]] of the field is approximately {{convert|980|ft|-1}} [[Sea level|above sea level]]. ==Layout== {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Walla Walla |lat = 46.077 |long = -118.336 |caption = Location in the [[United States]] |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 240 }} {{Location map |USA Washington |relief = 1 |label = Walla Walla |position = bottom |lat = 46.077 |long = -118.336 |caption = Location in [[Washington (state)|Washington]] |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 200 }} The layout of Borleske Stadium is like most minor league ballparks, although it is unconventionally oriented southeast. The entrance gate is just beyond right field. From the entrance you will find customer service, only in use during [[Walla Walla Sweets]] games, here you can get Borleske Bulletins, [[Walla Walla Sweets]] newsletter, and any regular customer service needs. To the right of customer service you will find the general admission area known as section F, also you will find the Laht Neppur Outfield Pub, only during Sweets games. Continuing left of customer service, going down the path you will find, on your right, you will find the grill also known as The Sweets spot. On you left you will find the main concession stand dubbed Sluggers:Ballpark Favorites. Here you can find a wide range of ballpark favorites found [https://web.archive.org/web/20140421212930/http://wallawallasweets.com/stadium/food/ Here]. To the right of Sluggers you will find the Sweets Shoppe, where you can find all your [[Walla Walla Sweets]] gear. Going down the path, on the left you can see the marvelous Grandstands of Borleske Stadium. They are broken into 4 parts, seating sections A, B, C, and D they are broken up by a set of staircases. On the opposite side of the Grandstands and before the playing field you will see the box seats, only available during Sweets games, they are the closest to the action. Continuing down the main walkway you will see the visiting team's dugout. Then, up ahead, you will find the crown jewel of Borleske Stadium, the Diamond and Premier Sections of Borleske Stadium. Used during all games of Borleske Stadium, they are the only [[Stadium seating|stadium style seating]] in the stadium. Then continuing down the main walkway, and to the right, you will find the other section of [[Bleacher]]s. Section E is the last seating are in the park. It is made of a combination on [[plastic]], [[wood]], and [[metal]]. Finally, the last part of Borleske Stadium is the [[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]] Beer Garden. It is the only part of Borleske that is not to move that is not part of seating part of Borleske Stadium that is not seating related. Alcohol is only available during [[Walla Walla Sweets|Sweets]] games. Also, absolutely no external food or drink is allowed past the gates of Borleske Stadium. ===Renovations=== ====Field Boxes==== Six field boxes were added right along the fence along the first base line.{{cite web |url=http://wallawallasweets.com/stadium/history/ |publisher=Walla Walla Sweets |title=Borleske Stadium history |accessdate=July 22, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819023027/http://wallawallasweets.com/stadium/history/ |archivedate=August 19, 2014 |df= }} Each field box holds 10 seats and every two boxes are served by a stadium waiter. The first three boxes include protective netting - an indicator of just how close to the action these boxes are! All six come with drink/snack trays and daily, complimentary Sweets programs, stuffed with a Budweiser scorecard and the daily Sherwin Williams Borleske Bulletin. ====Diamond/Premier Seats==== The Diamond (AA & BB) and Premier (CC & DD) seating sections are located directly behind home plate. A total of 252 stadium-style seats were added, 14 of which are Physically Disabled Accessible along with 14 companion seats. The premier seats come with waiter service for your convenience, so you will never miss any of the action! ====The Sweets Shoppe==== The Sweets Shoppe at Borleske Stadium is a fully functioning point of sale for all Sweets' merchandise, hats, clothing and apparel. It opens one hour before first pitch and closes during the 9th inning on a daily basis. The Sweets Shoppe is located on the main concourse directly across from the Concessions Stand. ====Concessions Stand==== The complete overhaul of the Borleske Stadium Concessions Stand included a new range and freezer/refrigeration system, a new three-section sink for proper cleaning, a new floor, new walls and three new points of sale to allow customers to move in and out of the concessions area quickly. ====The Sweet Spot==== Located down the right field line, nestled up against the visiting bullpen is the Sweet Spot presented by Key Technology. The Sweet Spot serves as a party deck for group ticket holders over 20 that elect for an all-you-can-eat BBQ starting a half hour before gates open to the public and running up to first pitch. The Sweet Spot has a 100-person capacity and houses the Borleske Stadium covered grill. ====Dugouts==== The new and improved dugouts at Borleske Stadium are sunken into the ground and feature a double-deck seating area, artificial surface at ground level to walk on and view the game, a storage area for helmets and bats and a protective netting that runs the length of each dugout to keep foul balls from screaming into the sitting area without obstructing the view from within. ====Budweiser Beer Garden==== Many adults at Borleske Stadium find their way down the left field line to the [[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]] Beer Garden. The Bud Barn serves Budweiser products and local micro brews along with several local wines. It is a popular spectating area, providing umbrella-covered tables and chairs and starting in 2011, pub tables and bar stools. ==Former tenants== *Whitman College football *Walla Walla High School baseball *Walla Walla Community College football *Walla Walla Bears (1969, 1983) *Walla Walla Islanders (1972){{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=B65YAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UvcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4742%2C1162397 |newspaper=The Bulletin |location=Bend, Oregon |title=No Rainbows this year |date=February 18, 1972 |page=8}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qgg0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=v_cDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6617%2C5391024 |newspaper=The Bulletin |location=Bend, Oregon |last=Anstine |first=Dennis |title=Rainbows over Walla Walla |date=June 23, 1972 |page=14}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TZFYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Y_gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2631%2C3167858 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |title=Walla Walla seeks crown in Tribe's last home series |date=August 25, 1972 |page=13 }} *Walla Walla Phillies (1970, 1971){{cite news |location=Bend, Oregon |title=Padres leaving Tri-City |agency=UPI |date=September 15, 1972 |page=11}} ==Current tenants== *Whitman College baseball *[[Walla Walla Sweets]] *Walla Walla High School news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KKNYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nvgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7297%2C1131118 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |last=Stewart |first=Chuck |title=Movie star seeking success in baseball role |date=June 20, 1972 |page=15 }} *[[Ozzie Smith]] (MLB Hall of Famer), with Walla Walla Padres (1977) *[[Tony Gwynn]] (MLB Hall of Famer), with Walla Walla Padres (1981) *[[John Kruk]] (former MLB All-Star), with Walla Walla Padres (1981) *[[Drew Bledsoe]] (NFL quarterback), first selection of the [[1993 NFL Draft]], Walla Walla High School (class of 1990) *[[Howie Bedell]]https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Walla_Walla_Bears *[[Bob Beall]]https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Walla_Walla_Phillies *[[Dane Iorg]] *[[Tom Trebelhorn]]https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Walla_Walla_Islanders ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://wallawallasweets.com/stadium/ Walla Walla Sweets: Borleske
