'''Capannelle Racecourse''' (Italian: '''Ippodromo delle Capannelle''') is a [[horse racing]] venue in [[Rome]], [[Italy]]. The course was constructed in 1881, and it was rebuilt in 1926 to a design by [[Paolo Vietti-Violi]].
It is the venue of three [[Conditions races|Group 1]] [[Flat racing|flat races]] – the [[Premio Presidente della Repubblica]], the [[Premio Lydia Tesio]] and the [[Premio Roma]]. The track also stages the most valuable flat race in Italy, the [[Derby Italiano]], which was downgraded to Group 2 status in 2009.
Group 2 races include the [[Premio Ribot]]. Group 3 races include the [[Premio Carlo Chiesa]], [[Premio Carlo e Francesco Aloisi]], [[Premio Carlo d'Alessio]], and [[Premio Guido Berardelli]].
It is also home ground of Italy's premier cricket club, Capannelle Roma.
==References== * [http://www.capannelleippodromo.it/ippodromo.html capannelleippodromo.it] – ''"L'Ippodromo" (in Italian)'' * [http://www.capannelleippodromo.it/ippodromo_storia.html capannelleippodromo.it] – ''"La Storia" (in Italian)'' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081230212714/http://www.initaly.com/regions/latium/rosemar2.htm initaly.com] – ''"Remembering Italy – Capannelle Race Course"'' * [http://www.racingandsports.com.au/breeding/rsNewsArt.asp?NID=144228&story=Italian_Derby_Downgraded racingandsports.com.au] – ''"Italian Derby Downgraded"'' * [http://www.rccc.it rccc.it] – ''Roma Capannelle Cricket Club''

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2018}} [[File:Mordiro.jpg|thumb|Coasteering near [[Porthclais]], [[Pembrokeshire]]]] '''Coasteering''' is a physical activity that encompasses movement along the [[intertidal zone]] of a rocky coastline on foot or by swimming, without the aid of boats, surf boards or other craft. It is difficult to define the precise boundaries between, for example, rockpooling and ocean swimming. Coasteering may include all or some of the following: *''Swimming or Adventure Swimming:'' in calm water; rough or white water; and/ or tidal currents. Dressing for swimming in the sea ([[wetsuit]]s, buoyancy aids etc.) is an integral part of Coasteering; even on routes where it is possible to stay dry. A route, or activity, where the group start out with the intention of staying dry - whether through route choice or the use of ropes and harnesses - is not coasteering. *''Climbing, scrambling, canyoning, sea level traversing:'' the very nature of the coastline that is needed for coasteering demands aspects of these activities. Ropes, as security on rock, are not used. Any climbing activity usually takes place above deep water, with safety spotters used where appropriate. There is a similarity to the sport of [[deep-water soloing]], but this would normally be carried out by experienced individuals not wearing equipment suitable for coasteering. Coasteering is never a dry, climbing activity. *''Jumping and Diving:'' are often seen as an appealing and exciting part of coasteering. These activities actually make up minimal content of a coasteering session.
A defining factor of coasteering is the opportunity provided by the marine geology for moving in the “impact zone” where water, waves, rocks, gullies, caves etc., come together to provide a very high energy environment.
==History== Although all aspects of coasteering have been informally practised by people for a very long time, if only as a means of access to a cut-off cove beyond a headland, the term appears first to have been used in 1973. In the book ''Sea Cliff Climbing'', John Cleare and Robin Collomb said "A few enthusiasts believe that coasteering will become popular and has a big future".
In the 1990s, it emerged as a commercially guided recreational activity initially along the cliff coastline of [[Pembrokeshire]] in [[Wales]]. By 1997 write-ups started appearing in the travel/recreational pages of the newspapers showing that several commercial companies were offering such activity.
In 1999, one guide company licensed a trade mark incorporating the word "Coasteering" in a distinctive script. However, the word was by then in general use to describe the activity.
The activity then spread to all regions of the UK where there are suitable rocky coasts, including Cornwall, Pembrokeshire, Anglesey and the Highlands and Isles of Scotland.
Dorset was one of the last counties with a suitable coastline to offer coasteering, with commercial providers starting to offer the activity as late as 2009; However Dorset is now arguably the busiest coasteering destination in the UK with upwards of 10,000 paying clients every year.
The advisory organisation for coasteering is the National Coasteering Charter (NCC).
In the UK the activity is recognized by the [http://www.hse.gov.uk/aala/index.htm Adventure Activities Licensing Authority] which is a department of the [[Health and Safety Executive]].
==Guided adventure experience== The rocky cliff coasts of western Britain provide the world's principal location for organised guided coasteering, where it is available from over 100 activity centres.<ref>[http://www.aals.org.uk/aals/provider_results.php?provider_name=&town=&county=&region=&Climbing=34&Watersports=&Trekking=&Caving=&Submit=Search List of AALA Recognized Providers for Combined Rock and Water Activities]</ref> Usually half day or one day trips are offered at a variety of levels catering for beginners, intermediates and advanced. Some trips are especially slanted towards study of the [[coastal ecology]].
Some centres cater for parties of school children.
==Adventure races== Coasteering may be included as one of the disciplines for a stage of an [[adventure racing|adventure race]]. This is especially common in New Zealand, but is also to be found in Australia, Canada, and the USA.
==Safety== In the UK, the [[Health and Safety Executive|HSE]] has an information sheet of good practice for the Adventure Activities Industry [http://www.hse.gov.uk/pubns/etis13.pdf].
===Basic safety equipment=== Safety equipment reflects the environment in which the sport is performed and often includes: *[[Wetsuit]] (for cooler waters outside the tropics) *Protective clothing and gloves to prevent abrasions - may be provided by the wet suit *Shoes to provide grip on rocks *Buoyancy aid *Helmet
===Hazards=== Because of the diverse practices involved in the sport there are a number of hazards.<ref>[http://www.hse.gov.uk/pubns/etis13.pdf HSE Information Sheet for Combined Water and Rock Activities]</ref> * Impact with rocks * Drowning * Hypothermia
==See also== * [[Bouldering]] * [[Caving]] * [[Outdoor activity]] * [[Scrambling]] * [[Seatrekking]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|Coasteering}}
{{Extreme sports}}
[[Category:Individual sports]] [[Category:Water sports]]

{{redirect|CETA|the US jobs and training program (1973-1982)|Comprehensive Employment and Training Act}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox treaty | name = Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement | long_name = | image = [[File:European Union Canada Locator.svg|frameless]] | image_alt = <!-- alt-text here for accessibility; see [[MOS:ACCESS]] --> | caption = Canada (orange) and the European Union (green) | type = Trade agreement | context = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 30 October 2016 | location_signed = Brussels | date_sealed = | date_effective = Not in force (parts are provisionally applied) | condition_effective = Approval by all signatories |provisional_application={{dts|21 September 2017}}<ref name=prov/> | signatories = *{{flag|Canada}} *{{flag|European Union}} *{{noflag|All 28 EU member states}} | parties = <!-- format this as a bullet list --> | ratifiers = 10 EU members<ref name=depositaryEU>{{cite web|url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/documents-publications/agreements-conventions/agreement/?aid=2016017|work=Council of the EU|accessdate=28 August 2017|title=Agreement Details}}</ref> | depositor = <!-- OR: --> | depositories = <!-- format this as a bullet list --> | citations = <!-- format as XX [[Article on Treaty Series|TS]] YYY --> | languages = {{collapsible list |titlestyle = background:transparent;text-align:left;font-weight:normal; |title = All official EU/Canadian languages | {{hlist |[[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]] |[[Croatian language|Croatian]] |[[Czech language|Czech]] |[[Danish language|Danish]] |[[Dutch language|Dutch]] |[[English language|'''English''']] |[[Estonian language|Estonian]] |[[Finnish language|Finnish]] |[[French language|'''French''']] |[[German language|German]] |[[Greek language|Greek]] |[[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] |[[Irish language|Irish]] |[[Italian language|Italian]] |[[Latvian language|Latvian]] |[[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] |[[Maltese language|Maltese]] |[[Polish language|Polish]] |[[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] |[[Romanian language|Romanian]] |[[Slovak language|Slovak]] |[[Slovene language|Slovene]] |[[Spanish language|Spanish]] |[[Swedish language|Swedish]]}} }} | wikisource = <!-- OR: --> | wikisource1 = <!-- Up to 5 wikisourceN variables may be specified --> | footnotes = | image_width = 350px | date_expiration = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} OR: --> }} The '''Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement''' ('''CETA''') is a [[free-trade agreement]] between [[Canada]], the [[European Union]] and its member states.<ref name="ec"/><ref name="canada"/><ref name="GMtentative">https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/belgians-reach-deal-on-eu-canada-free-trade-agreement/article32542390/</ref> It has been provisionally applied,<ref>http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2017/september/tradoc_156062.pdf</ref> so the [[treaty]] has eliminated 98% of the tariffs between Canada and the EU.
The negotiations were concluded in August 2014. All [[Member state of the European Union|28 European Union member states]] approved the final text of CETA for signature, with [[Belgium]] being the final country to give its approval.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://euobserver.com/economic/135717|title=Belgium green lights unchanged Ceta|access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> [[Justin Trudeau]], Prime Minister of Canada, travelled to Brussels on 30 October 2016 to sign on behalf of Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yorkregion.com/news-story/6934897-trudeau-brussels-bound-to-sign-ceta-on-sunday/|title=Trudeau Brussels-bound to sign CETA on Sunday|last=YorkRegion.com|website=www.yorkregion.com|access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> The European Parliament approved the deal on 15 February 2017.<ref name="auto">{{cite news | title=CETA: MEPs back EU-Canada trade agreement | author=Bálint Péter Linder | date=2017-02-15 | publisher=European Parliament Press Service | url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/news-room/20170209IPR61728/ceta-meps-back-eu-canada-trade-agreement}}</ref> The agreement is subject to ratification by the EU and national legislatures<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/prime-minister-trudeau-signs-canada-eu-trade-deal-in-brussels/article32586423/|title=Trudeau signs CETA but final ratification still required by European Union|first=Paul|last=Waldie|date=30 October 2016|publisher=|via=The Globe and Mail}}</ref><ref name="GMtentative"/> and can only enter into force if no adverse opinion is given by the European Court of Justice following a request for an opinion by Belgium.<ref name=CJEUref/> Until its formal entry into force, substantial parts are provisionally applied from 21 September 2017.<ref name=prov>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_STATEMENT-17-1959_en.htm|work=European Commission|title=EU and Canada agree to set a date for the provisional application of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement. Statement by Mr. Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission and. Mr Justin Trudeau, Prime Minister of Canada|accessdate=9 September 2017|date=8 July 2017}}</ref>
The European Commission indicates the treaty will lead to savings of just over half a billion euros in taxes for EU exporters every year, mutual recognition in regulated professions such as architects, accountants and engineers, and easier transfers of company staff and other professionals between the EU and Canada. The European Commission claims CETA will create a more level playing field between Canada and the EU on intellectual property rights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2016/february/tradoc_154331.pdf|title=What will the EU gain from CETA?|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
Proponents of CETA emphasize that the agreement will boost trade between the EU and Canada and thus create new jobs, facilitate business operations by abolishing customs duties, goods checks, and various other levies, facilitate mutual recognition of diplomas and regulate investment disputes by creating a new system of courts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/croatia/news/eu_canada_trade_agreement_enters_into_force_hr|title=Trgovinski sporazum između EU-a i Kanade stupa na snagu—Hrvatska—European Commission|first=Ksenija|last=SKREBLIN|date=20 September 2017|website=Hrvatska—European Commission}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/hr/sporazum-o-slobodnoj-trgovini-ceta/a-40623781|title=Sporazum o slobodnoj trgovini CETA—Gospodarstvo—DW—21.09.2017|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(www.dw.com)|website=DW.COM}}</ref> Opponents consider that CETA would weaken European consumer rights, including high EU standards concerning [[food safety]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/gabriel-optimistic-over-eu-canada-ceta-trade-deal/a-36073644|title=Gabriel optimistic over EU-Canada CETA trade deal {{!}} Business {{!}} DW.COM {{!}} 18.10.2016|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref> and criticize it as a boon only for [[big business]] and [[multinational corporation]]s, while risking net-losses, unemployment, and environmental damage impacting individual citizens.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37450742|title=EU Commission refuses to revise Canada Ceta trade deal|date=2016-09-23|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tni.org/files/download/ceta-isds-en_0.pdf|title=Trading Away Democracy, HOW CETA’S INVESTOR PROTECTION RULES THREATEN THE PUBLIC GOOD IN CANADA AND THE EU|author1=Pia Eberhardt |author2=Blair Redlin |author3=Cecile Toubeau |date=November 2014|website=tni.org|publisher=Published by Association Internationale de Techniciens, Experts et Chercheurs (Aitec), Vienna Chamber of Labour (AK Vienna), Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives (CCPA), Corporate Europe Observatory (CEO), Council of Canadians, Canadian Union of Public Employees (CUPE), European Federation of Public Service Unions (EPSU), German NGO Forum on Environment & Development, Friends of the Earth Europe (FoEE), PowerShift, Quaker Council for European Affairs (QCEA), Quebec Network on Continental Integration (RQIC), Trade Justice Network, Transnational Institute (TNI), Transport & Environment (T&E).|access-date=22 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cela.ca/sites/cela.ca/files/1085-Standing%20Committee%20Submissions%20on%20CETA_Nov_30_2016.pdf|title=Submissions to the Standing Committee on International Trade Re: An Act to Implement the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (Bill C-30)|last=Blaise|first=Kerrie|date=30 Nov 2016|website=Canadian Environmental Law Association|publisher=Canadian Environmental Law Association|access-date=5 Dec 2016}}</ref> The deal also includes a controversial [[investor-state dispute settlement]] mechanism which makes critics fear that multinational corporations could sue national governments for billions of dollars if they thought that the government policies had a bad impact on their business.<ref name="auto1"/> A poll conducted by [[Angus Reid Institute]] in February 2017 concluded that 55 percent of Canadians support CETA, while only 10 percent oppose it. The support, however, has waned when compared to the poll conducted in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://angusreid.org/ceta-trudeau-europe/|title=CETA: As support softens, Canadians still back trade deal with Europe 5-to-1 over those who oppose it—Angus Reid Institute|date=14 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref> In contrast, the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) has a 44 percent support rate among Canadians in February 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://angusreid.org/trump-nafta-renegotiation/|title=Facing tough talk over NAFTA renegotiations, Canadians rediscover affection for the trade pact—Angus Reid Institute|date=12 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref> In contrast to Canada, the agreement has prompted protests in a number of European countries.
==History== CETA is Canada's biggest bilateral initiative since [[NAFTA]]. It was started as a result of a joint study "Assessing the Costs and Benefits of a Closer EU-Canada Economic Partnership",<ref name="link to study"/> which was released in October 2008. Officials announced the launch of negotiations on 6 May 2009 at the Canada-EU Summit in [[Prague]].<ref name="canada"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://eeas.europa.eu/delegations/canada/eu_canada/trade_relation/ceta/index_en.htm |website=Delegation of the EU to Canada |publisher=European External Action Service |accessdate=22 October 2014 |ref=towards-ceta |title=Towards a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505112357/http://eeas.europa.eu/delegations/canada/eu_canada/trade_relation/ceta/index_en.htm |archivedate=5 May 2015 }}</ref> This, after the Canada-EU Summit in Ottawa on 18 March 2004 where leaders agreed to a framework for a new Canada-EU Trade and Investment Enhancement Agreement (TIEA). The TIEA was intended to move beyond traditional market access issues, to include areas such as trade and investment facilitation, competition, mutual recognition of professional qualifications, financial services, e-commerce, temporary entry, small- and medium-sized enterprises, [[sustainable development]], and sharing science and technology. The TIEA was also to build on a Canada-EU regulatory co-operation framework for promoting bilateral co-operation on approaches to regulatory governance, advancing good regulatory practices and facilitating trade and investment. In addition to lowering barriers, the TIEA was meant to heighten Canadian and European interest in each other's markets.<ref name="TIEA"/> The TIEA continued until 2006 when Canada and the EU decided to pause negotiations. This led to negotiations on a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), and this agreement will go beyond the TIEA toward an agreement with a much broader and more ambitious scope. [[File:Stop TTIP-CETA Protest in Brussels 20-09-2016 (06).jpg|thumb|The Stop TTIP-CETA protest in [[Brussels]], Belgium, 20 September 2016]]
An agreement in principle was signed by Canadian Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] and [[European Commission]] President [[José Manuel Barroso]] on 18 October 2013. The negotiations were concluded on 1 August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/entwurf-fuer-ceta-verhandlungen-ueber-freihandelsabkommen-mit-kanada-abgeschlossen-1.2078844 |accessdate=2012-08-06 |title=Verhandlungen über Freihandelsabkommen mit Kanada abgeschlossen (Negotiations with Canada on freetrade agreement completed) |date=2012-08-06}}</ref> The trade agreement was officially presented on 25 September 2014 by Harper and Barroso during an EU - Canada Summit at the Royal York Hotel in downtown [[Toronto]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.embassynews.ca/news/2014/09/24/%E2%80%98symbolic%E2%80%99-leaders%E2%80%99-summit-to-mark-the-end-of-ceta-talks/46100|accessdate=2014-09-25 |title="Symbolic" summit to mark end of CETA talks |date=2014-09-24}}</ref> The Canada Europe Roundtable for Business has served as the parallel business process from the launch to the conclusion of the CETA negotiations.
After it had been leaked by German public television on 14 August, the 1634 pages long Consolidated CETA text was published on the EU's official website on 26 September 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2014/september/tradoc_152806.pdf |title=Consolidated CETA Text |accessdate=27 September 2014}}</ref>
Completion, translation of the final text into 24 EU languages, and ratification is expected to take years since the passage of the deal approval of the [[European Parliament]] and the [[European Council]] as well as Canada and the individual [[EU member states|28 EU member states]] as well.<ref>{{cite news | title=CETA: Canada-EU free trade deal lauded by Harper, Barroso | author=Laura Payton | date=2013-10-18 | publisher=CBC News | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ceta-canada-eu-free-trade-deal-lauded-by-harper-barroso-1.2125122}}</ref><ref name="The Star">{{cite news| url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2012/04/26/canadaeurope_trade_deal_risks_derailment_over_visa_spat.html | location=Toronto | work=The Star | title=Canada-Europe deal risks derailment over visa spat}}</ref>
==Research commissioned by negotiating parties== {{Update|documentation|date=February 2016}} The EU-Canada Trade Sustainability Impact Assessment (SIA), a three-part study commissioned by the European Commission to independent experts and completed in September 2011, provides a comprehensive prediction on the impacts of CETA.<ref name="SIAF"/><ref name="SIAFA"/><ref name="FB"/> It predicts a number of macro-economic and sector-specific impacts, suggesting the EU may see increases in real GDP of 0.02–0.03% in the long-term from CETA, whereas Canada may see increases of 0.18–0.36%; the Investment section of the report suggests these numbers could be higher when factoring in investment increases. At the sectoral level, the study predicts the greatest gains in output and trade to be stimulated by services liberalization and by the removal of tariffs applied on sensitive agricultural products; it also suggests CETA could have a positive social impact if it includes provisions on the ILO's Core Labour Standards and Decent Work Agenda. The study details a variety of impacts in various "cross-cutting" components of CETA: it advocates against controversial NAFTA-style [[Investor State Dispute Settlement|ISDS]] provisions; predicts potentially imbalanced benefits from a government procurement (GP) chapter; assumes CETA will lead to an upward harmonization in [[intellectual property|IPR]] regulations, particularly changing Canadian IPR laws; and predicts impacts in terms of competition policy and several other areas.<ref name=FB/>
==Economic ties between the EU and Canada== Canada and the EU have a long history of economic co-operation. Comprising 28 Member States with a total population of over 500 million and a GDP of €13.0 trillion in 2012,<ref>{{cite web|title=Gross domestic product at market prices|url=http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/tgm/refreshTableAction.do;jsessionid=9ea7d07d30df81d7d40a2e93409b986efd20d5e17291.e34MbxeSaxaSc40LbNiMbxeNaNaNe0?tab=table&plugin=1&pcode=tec00001&language=en|publisher=Eurostat|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref> the European Union (EU) is the world's largest single market, foreign investor and trader. As an integrated bloc, the EU represents Canada's second largest trading partner in goods and services. In 2008, Canadian goods and services exports to the EU totalled [[Canadian dollar|C$]]52.2 billion, an increase of 3.9% from 2007, and imports from the EU amounted to $62.4 billion.
According to [[Statistics Canada]], the EU is also the second largest source of [[foreign direct investment]] (FDI) in Canada, with the stock of FDI amounting to $133.1 billion at the end of 2008. In 2008, the stock of Canada's direct investment in the EU totalled $136.6 billion, and the EU is the destination of 21.4% of Canadian direct investment abroad. According to [[Eurostat]], the EU identified Canada as its third largest destination and its fourth largest source of FDI in 2007.
== Copyright provisions == {{POV|date=November 2017}}
Many of its [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement#Copyright provisions|provisions on copyright]] were initially thought to be identical to the controversial [[Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement|ACTA]], which was rejected by the [[European Parliament]] in 2012. The European Commission has indicated<ref>http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2012/august/tradoc_149866.pdf</ref> that this is not the case.
Part of the Agreement is stricter enforcement of intellectual property, including [[Legal liability|liability]] for [[Internet Service Provider]]s, a ban on technologies that can be used to circumvent copyright.<ref name="eff"/> After failure of [[ACTA]] the copyright language in CETA was substantially watered down.<ref name=AuFTA>{{cite new|url=http://copyrightblog.kluweriplaw.com/2018/08/02/future-eu-australia-fta-copyright-expect-ip-chapter/|title=Future EU-Australia FTA and copyright: what could we expect in the IP chapter?|date=August 2, 2018|accessdate=7 September 2018|work=Kluwer Copyright Blog|author=Rita Matulionyte}}</ref> The following provisions remain:
{{quote| * '''WIPO ratification.''' The EU asked that Canada respect the rights and obligations under the [[WIPO]] Internet treaties. The EU only formally ratified those treaties in the week of 16 December 2009. * '''Anti-circumvention provisions.''' The EU asked that Canada implement anti-circumvention provisions that include a ban on the distribution of circumvention devices. There is no such requirement in the WIPO Internet treaties. * '''ISP Liability provisions.''' The treaty requires both EU and Canada to enact [[Safe harbor (law)|safe harbor]] statutory provisions that would limit ISPs liability where they act as mere conduits, cache content, or host content. These protections may not be conditioned on service provides monitoring their service for possible infringements. * '''Enforcement provisions.''' The EU asked that Canada establish new enforcement provisions including measures to preserve evidence, ordering alleged infringers to disclose information on a wide range of issue[s], mandate disclosure of banking information in commercial infringement cases, allow for [[injunctive relief]], and destruction of goods. There is also a full section on new border measures requirements. * '''Making available or distribution rights.''' The EU asked that Canada implement a distribution or making available right to copyright owners.
These are just the copyright provisions. There are sections dealing with patents, trademarks, designs, and (coming soon) geographical indications. These include:
* requiring Canada to comply with the [[Trademark Law Treaty]] (Canada is not a contracting party) * requiring Canada to accede to the [[Hague Agreement Concerning the International Deposit of Industrial Designs|Hague System for the International Registration of Industrial Designs]] * creating new legal protections for registered industrial designs including extending the term of protection from the current 10 years to up to 25 years * requiring Canada to comply with the [[Patent Law Treaty]] (Canada has signed but not implemented) * requiring Canada to establish enhanced protection for data submitted for pharmaceutical patents.|''Dr Michael Geist, Canada Research Chair in Internet and E-commerce Law, University of Ottawa''<ref name="geist1"/> }}
On 22 October 2012, five Polish NGOs criticized the secrecy surrounding the negotiations, the similarities to ACTA, and demanded more disclosures about the negotiations from the Polish government.<ref>{{cite web|author=Wyślij |url=http://prawokultury.pl/newsy/list-5-organizacji-pozarzadowych-do-minstra-kultur/ |title=List 5 organizacji pozarządowych do Ministra Kultury i Ministra Gospodarki w sprawie umowy CETA :: Prawo kultury |language=pl |publisher=Prawokultury.pl |date= |accessdate=2012-10-23}}</ref>
In the Consolidated CETA Text a long section on "Intellectual Property Rights", IPR, (pp. 339–375) deals comprehensively with copyrights, trademarks, patents, designs, trade secrets and licensing. Here reference is made to the [[TRIPS]] agreement (p. 339 f). In addition to the interests of the pharmaceutical and software industries CETA encourages to prosecute "Camcording" (the so-called "film piracy", Art. 5.6, p. 343). Especially the negotiations on food exports lasted very long. The interests connected with European cheese exports and Canadian beef exports led to a protection of these kinds of intellectual properties and long lists of "Geographical Indications Identifying a Product Originating in the European Union" (pp. 363–347).<ref name="Consolidated CETA Text">{{cite web|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/wirtschaft/ceta-dokument-101.pdf |accessdate=2014-08-15 |title=Consolidated CETA Text |work=EUROPEAN COMMISSION, Directorate-General for Trade |date=2014-08-05}}</ref>
== Non-tariff barriers == {{see also|Non-tariff barriers to trade}} ===Agricultural=== CETA does not alter EU non-tariff barriers such as European regulations on beef, which include a ban on the use of growth hormones. Canadian stakeholders have criticized the EU's delays in the approval process for genetically modified organisms (GMOs), and GMO traceability and labelling requirements, none of which are addressed in CETA.<ref>{{cite web|title=Canada–European Union Economic and Trade Negotiations: The Agri-food Sector|publisher=[[Parliament of Canada]]|year=2011|accessdate=11 March 2014|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/content/lop/researchpublications/cei-25-e.htm?Param=ce5}}</ref>
=== Environmental === Both the EU and Canada will retain the right to regulate freely in areas of public interest such as environmental protection, or people's health and safety.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ec.europa.eu/trade/policy/in-focus/ceta/#democracy|title=CETA—EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|newspaper=Trade—European Commission|access-date=2016-10-29}}</ref>
===Impact on fisheries=== {{update-section|date=August 2017}} [[File:Newfoundland_Grand_Banks_and_EEZ_border.png|thumb|right|300px|The enforcement of the [[Exclusive economic zone]] of Canada will be altered under the CETA.{{Citation needed|reason=no articles seem to say that the EEZ will be changed|date=June 2017}}]]
The provincial government of [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] has argued that the Federal government of Canada in Ottawa reneged on a deal to pay $280 million in exchange for its relinquishment of minimum processing requirements as part of CETA. Those rules helped protect jobs in fish plants, especially in rural areas hit hard by the [[Collapse of the Atlantic northwest cod fishery|cod moratorium, which was instituted in 1992]].<ref name=gm15>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/newfoundland-and-labrador-says-talks-at-stalemate-with-ottawa-over-fish-fund/article24616519/ G+M: "Newfoundland and Labrador says talks at stalemate with Ottawa over fish fund"], 26 May 2015</ref> The [[exclusive economic zone]] of Canada, which was the subject of the 1992 [[Canada–France Maritime Boundary Case]] dispute, will no longer be in force where fishing boats from Europe are concerned. Overly permissive Spanish fishing practices, as evinced by the [[Turbot War]], have been reduced, and the European practice of [[R v Secretary of State for Transport, ex p Factortame Ltd|Factortame Ltd]] will be pursued.{{Citation needed|reason=no articles seem to say that the EEZ will be changed|date=June 2017}}
===Visa disputes=== The Czech Republic, Romania and Bulgaria had declared they would not endorse the agreement, in effect scuppering the entire agreement, until the visa requirements for their citizens entering Canada were lifted.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/bulgaria-romania-tie-eu-canada-deal-to-visa-free-travel-05-16-2016|title=Bulgaria, Romania Tie EU-Canada Deal to Visas :: Balkan Insight|website=www.balkaninsight.com|access-date=2016-10-29}}</ref> All other EU countries already had visa free travel to Canada. Visas requirements were lifted for the Czech Republic on November 14, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|author=all: Economia, a.s. |url=http://hn.ihned.cz/c1-60249600-viza-do-kanady-brzy-skonci |title=Víza do Kanady brzy skončí | HN.IHNED.CZ - česko |publisher=Hn.Ihned.Cz |date= |accessdate=2014-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/234748-cesi-budou-uz-brzy-letat-do-kanady-opet-bez-viz/ |title=Češi budou už brzy létat do Kanady opět bez víz — Domácí — ČT24 — Česká televize |publisher=Ceskatelevize.cz |date=2013-07-15 |accessdate=2014-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/department/media/releases/2013/2013-11-14.asp|title=Canada News Centre - Search Results|first=Government of|last=Canada,|date=30 October 2016|publisher=cic.gc.ca}}</ref> Canada has given a written undertaking to cancel visa requirements for Bulgarian and Romanian nationals visiting Canada for business and tourism, within a timeframe no later than the end of 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/report-romania-reaches-visa-deal-with-canada/|title=Romania reaches visa deal with Canada: report|date=2016-10-21|newspaper=POLITICO|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sofiaglobe.com/2016/10/25/bulgarian-government-approves-signing-of-eu-canada-ceta-deal/|title=Bulgarian government approves signing of EU-Canada CETA deal|date=2016-10-25|website=The Sofia Globe|access-date=2016-10-29}}</ref> Canada lifted visa requirements for Bulgarian and Romanian citizens on 1 December 2017.<ref>[https://www.canada.ca/eTA canada.ca/eTA]</ref><ref>[https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/visit-canada/entry-requirements-country.html#visaExempt Entry requirements by country:Visa-exempt]</ref>
== Investment protection and investor-state-tribunals == {{See also|Investor-state dispute settlement}}
Section 4 of the CETA agreement (pages 158–161) provides Investment Protection to foreign investors, and guarantees a "fair and equitable treatment and full protection and security".
CETA allows foreign corporations to sue states before [[Investor-state dispute settlement|arbitral tribunals]] if they claim to have suffered losses because a state had violated its Non Discriminatory Treatment obligations (CETA, section 3, p 156 f) or because of a violation of the guaranteed investment protection.
This license exists only in one direction—states cannot sue companies in these investor-state arbitrations. Such investors complaints are nothing new under public international law ([[UNCTAD]] listed 514 such cases at the end of 2012, most from the United States, the Netherlands, Great Britain and Germany) but for transatlantic trade and investment, this comprehensive level of parallel justice is new.
After much criticism of the hitherto often confidential arbitral proceedings, CETA now provides for a certain amount of transparency by declaring the [[UNCITRAL]] Rules on Transparency in Treaty-based Investor-State Arbitration applicable to all proceedings (article X.33: Transparency of proceedings, p. 174).
While there is no appeal mechanism against arbitration awards comparable to scrutiny of court judgments, awards made under CETA are subject to [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes|ICSID]] (International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes) annulment proceedings if the claim is brought under the ICSID Rules, or setting-aside proceedings if the claim is brought under the UNCITRAL Rules or any other rules the parties have agreed on. Only after time limits set for these review mechanisms have lapsed, is the tribunal's final award to "be binding between the disputing parties and in respect of that particular case". (article X.39: Enforcement of awards, p. 177)
On 26 March 2014, German Economics Minister [[Sigmar Gabriel]] wrote an open letter to EU Trade Commissioner [[Karel De Gucht]], stating that investment protection was central sensitive point, which could in the end decide whether a transatlantic free trade agreement would meet with German approval. He further stated that investment arbitration was unnecessary between countries with well-developed legal systems.
The CETA "[[Investor-state dispute settlement|Investor-State Dispute Settlement]]" (ISDS) provisions could create a precedent for similar arrangements within [[TTIP]]. Furthermore, critics allege that CETA would allow US companies to sue EU states through Canadian subsidiaries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/trade-society/news/us-multinationals-could-sue-eu-governments-through-ceta/|title=US multinationals could sue EU governments through CETA|website=EurActiv.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.commondreams.org/newswire/2016/09/19/canada-eu-deal-likely-result-deluge-big-business-cases-brought-against-european|title=Canada-EU Deal Likely to Result in ‘Deluge’ of Big Business Cases Brought Against European Governments|newspaper=Common Dreams|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/if-youre-worried-about-ttip-then-you-need-to-know-about-ceta-a6671886.html|title=If you're worried about TTIP, then you need to know about CETA|date=2015-09-29|newspaper=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref>
In 2016, the EU Commission announced that it had agreed with the Canadian government to replace ''ad hoc'' arbitral tribunals in CETA with a permanent dispute settlement tribunal. The tribunal will consist of 15 members named by Canada and the EU, dealing with individual cases in panels of three. An appeals mechanism will be established to ensure "legal correctness" of awards. The tribunal's members may not appear as experts or party counsel in other investment cases.<ref>[http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/press/index.cfm?id=1468 CETA: EU and Canada agree on new approach on investment in trade agreement], EU Commission Press Release, 29 February 2016</ref>
==Signature and ratification== [[Image:Parlement wallon - CETA.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Banner opposing CETA at the [[Walloon Parliament]] in [[Namur]] on 19 October 2016.]] It was initially unclear whether or not the EU member states had to ratify the agreement, as the European Commission considered the treaty to be solely in the competence of the EU.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/8e9428d4-412a-11e6-9b66-0712b3873ae1|title=National ratification issue could derail EU-Canada trade deal|date=3 July 2016|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref> However, in July 2016 it was decided that CETA be qualified as a "mixed agreement" and thus be ratified through national procedures as well.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.eppgroup.eu/press-release/The-ratification-of-CETA-by-national-parliaments|title=The ratification of CETA by national parliaments – a stepping stone in the transition from the old world of trade towards the new world of international trade|date=13 July 2016|publisher=EPP Group}}</ref>
Shortly before the scheduled signature of CETA on 27 October 2016, Belgium announced it was unable to sign the treaty, as assent is required by all regional governments. The federal government and Flanders, which are governed by the centre-right [[Michel Government|Michel]] and [[Bourgeois Government|Bourgeois]] governments respectively, are in favour, whereas the [[French Community of Belgium|French Community]], [[Wallonia]] and [[Brussels]], which are led by centre-left parties that are in opposition at federal level, rejected signature in its current form. On 27 April 2016, the [[Walloon Parliament]] had already adopted a resolution in opposition to CETA. On 13 October 2016, [[David Lametti]] defended CETA before a Walloon Parliament committee.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.rtbf.be/info/belgique/detail_ceta-le-vice-ministre-canadien-defend-des-valeurs-communes-devant-le-parlement-wallon?id=9428885|title=CETA: le vice-ministre canadien défend des "valeurs communes" devant le Parlement wallon|publisher=RTBF|date=13 October 2016}}</ref> However, the next day the Walloon Parliament affirmed its opposition. Walloon Minister-President [[Paul Magnette]] led the intra-Belgian opposition shortly before the planned signature.
The intra-Belgian disagreement was solved in the final days of October, paving the way for CETA's signature. On 28 October, the Belgian regional parliaments allowed [[Full Powers]] to be given to the federal government, and the following day Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Didier Reynders]] gave his signature on behalf of Belgium.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deredactie.be/permalink/1.2805902|title=Reynders heeft handtekening gezet onder Belgisch akkoord voor CETA|date=29 October 2016|publisher=deredactie.be}}</ref><ref>[http://nautilus.parlement-wallon.be/Archives/2016_2017/MOTION/633_3.pdf MOTION déposée en conclusion du débat sur l’Accord économique et commercial global (AECG–CETA)]. Doc. 633 (2016-2017) N° 3. [http://nautilus.parlement-wallon.be/Archives/2016_2017/CRI/cri6.pdf#page=34 P.W.—C.R.I. N° 6 (2016–2017)—Vendredi 28 octobre 2016].</ref> The next day, on Sunday 30 October 2016, the treaty was signed by Canadian Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]], President of the European Council [[Donald Tusk]], President of the European Commission [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] and Slovak Prime Minister [[Robert Fico]] (as [[Slovakia]] held the [[Presidency of the Council of the European Union]] in the second half of 2016).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ec.europa.eu/news/2016/10/20161030_en.htm|title=EU and Canada sign CETA|date=30 October 2016|publisher=European Commission}}</ref>
Following the signature, the consent by the [[European Parliament]] and the ratification by Canada, CETA applies provisionally since 21 September 2017,<ref>{{cite web|title=Notice concerning the provisional application of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?qid=1515577599150&uri=CELEX:22017X0916(02)|website=EUR-Lex}}</ref> awaiting its ratification by the European Union member states.
* The [[European Parliament]] approved the agreement on 15 February 2017;<ref name="auto"/> * The Latvian parliament, the [[Saeima]], ratified the agreement on 23 February 2017. * The [[Canadian Parliament]]'s bill on CETA, Bill C-30, received [[Royal Assent]] on 16 May 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=C-30: An Act to implement the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between Canada and the European Union and its Member States and to provide for certain other measures|url=http://www.parl.ca/LegisInfo/BillDetails.aspx?Language=E&billId=8549249|website=LEGISinfo|publisher=Parliament of Canada|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> The Canadian government had indicated that the agreement would be ratified on or before 1 July 2017,<ref>{{cite news|last1=McGregor|first1=Janyce|title='We are ready': Canada-Europe trade deal set to kick in, mostly, by July 1|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ceta-implementation-malmstrom-canada-1.4039484|accessdate=23 May 2017|work=CBC News|date=27 March 2017}}</ref> however dispute with the EU regarding details of implementation has delayed the ratification date.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McGregor|first1=Janyce|title=Canada's trade deal with itself now in effect, as EU deal waits|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/cfta-interprovincial-trade-july-1-1.4181380|accessdate=3 July 2017|agency=CBC News|date=2 July 2017}}</ref> After rounds of extensive discussions, the two sides announced that CETA will be provisionally applied on 21 September 2017, nearly three months later than the anticipated date of implementation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Canada, EU to provisionally apply CETA in September|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/ceta-september-provisionally-1.4196210|accessdate=13 July 2017|agency=CBC News|date=8 July 2017}}</ref> * The Danish parliament, the [[Folketing]], ratified the agreement on 1 June 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dlapiper.com/en/denmark/insights/publications/2017/06/denmark-ratifies-ceta/|title=Denmark is the second EU member-state to ratify CETA—Insights—DLA Piper Global Law Firm|website=DLA Piper}}</ref> * The Spanish parliament, the [[Cortes Generales]], ratified the agreement on 29 June 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2017/06/29/actualidad/1498721488_698452.html|title=El Congreso ratifica el CETA con críticas del PP y Ciudadanos al PSOE por su abstención|first=Fernando|last=Garea|date=29 June 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * The Croatian parliament, the [[Sabor]], ratified the agreement on 30 June 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lider.media/aktualno/biznis-i-politika/hrvatska/sabor-potvrdio-ceta-u/|title=Sabor potvrdio CETA-u|date=30 June 2017}}</ref> * The Czech parliament's upper house, the [[Senate of the Czech Republic]], ratified the agreement on 20 April 2017 and the Czech parliament's lower house, the [[Chamber of Deputies (Czech Republic)|Chamber of Deputies]], ratified the agreement on 13 September 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.praguemonitor.com/2017/04/21/senate-approves-free-trade-deal-canada|title=Senate approves free trade deal with Canada|date=20 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://praguemonitor.com/2017/09/14/lower-house-approves-ceta-agreement|title=Lower house approves CETA agreement|date=14 September 2017}}</ref> * The Portuguese parliament, the [[Assembleia da República]], ratified the agreement on 20 September 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dn.pt/lusa/interior/governo-aprova-acordo-comercial-com-o-canada-sem-apoio-dos-parceiros-8784621.html|title=Governo aprova acordo comercial com o Canadá sem apoio dos parceiros|date=20 September 2017}}</ref> * The Lithuanian parliament, the [[Seimas]], ratified the agreement on 24 April 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lrs.lt/sip/portal.show?p_r=119&p_k=1&p_t=257423|title=Seimas ratifikavo Kanados ir ES prekybos susitarimą su specialiu pareiškimu|date=24 April 2018}}</ref>
===Instruments of ratification=== Eleven states have deposited their instruments of ratification: Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, and the UK.<ref name=depositaryEU/>
===Legal challenge=== In September 2017, Belgium requested the opinion of the [[European Court of Justice]] on whether the dispute resolution system of CETA is compatible with EU law. The agreement cannot come into force until the ECJ has given its opinion nor if the ECJ opinion is that CETA is incompatible with EU law.<ref name=CJEUref>{{cite web|url=https://diplomatie.belgium.be/sites/default/files/downloads/ceta_summary.pdf|title=BELGIAN REQUEST FOR AN OPINION FROM THE EUROPEAN COURT OF JUSTICE|accessdate=9 September 2017|work=Government of Belgium}}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Club Humaitá (Mariano Roque Alonso)| fullname = Deportivo Humaitá Football Club| nickname = - | founded = February 19, 1932 | ground = [[Estadio Pioneros de Corumba Cué]],
[[Mariano Roque Alonso]] , [[Paraguay]] | capacity = 7,000 | image = [[Image:Humaita FBC.png|95px|Humaitá FBC Emblem]]| chairman = Paulo Cesar Pico | manager = Oscar Dominguez | league = Paraguayan Fourth Division | season = 2012 | position = 10° | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=_whitestripes|pattern_ra1=| leftarm1=ff0000|body1=ff0000|rightarm1=ff0000|shorts1=0000CC|socks1=ff0000| pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=| leftarm2=CDCDC1|body2=CDCDC1|rightarm2=CDCDC1|shorts2=ffffff|socks2=CDCDC1 }} '''Deportivo Humaitá''' is a Paraguayan [[football (soccer)]] club from the city of [[Mariano Roque Alonso]], in the [[Gran Asunción]] area. The club was founded in 1932. ==History== The club took its name from the historic Paraguayan city of [[Humaitá]]. It is the third oldest team from Mariano Roque Alonso and won 12 titles from the regional league of that city, before joining the Liga Paraguaya de Futbol and participating in the lower divisions with other metropolitan area teams. Its biggest achievement was promotion to the Paraguayan first division in 1993. It competed in the [[Liga Paraguaya: Segunda División|first division]] for three years before being relegated to the [[Liga Paraguaya: Segunda División|second division]]. Humaitá currently{{when|date=June 2015}} plays in the "Primera División Chilo" which is equivalent to the fourth division. ==Honours== *'''[[Liga Paraguaya: Segunda División|Paraguayan Second Division]]: 1''' ::1993 *'''[[Liga Paraguaya: Tercera División|Paraguayan Third Division]]: 1''' ::1988 *'''[[Paraguayan Cuarta División|Paraguayan Fourth Division]]: 1''' ::2001 *'''[[Paraguayan Segunda División|Paraguayan Second Division]]: 1''' Runner-up (1): 1991. ==External links== * [http://www.albigol.com/albigol_v3/template_eins.php?lang=en&sekt=segasc2&id=26 Albigol: Deportivo Humaita Info] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070315070935/http://www.teledeportes.com.py/ Paraguayan Soccer Info] {{-}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Deportivo Humaita}} [[Category:Football clubs in Paraguay|Humaita]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1932|Humaita]] [[Category:1932 establishments in Paraguay]] {{Paraguay-sport-stub}} {{SouthAm-footyclub-stub}}

([[Nuku'alofa]], [[Tonga]]; April 23, 2002) | Largest win = {{fbwu|20|TON}} 0 – 4 {{fbwu|20|FIJ}}
([[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]]; July 11, 2017) | Largest loss = {{fbwu|20|NZL}} 8 – 0 {{fbwu|20|FIJ}}

([[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]]; July 14, 2017) | World cup apps = | World cup first = | World cup best = | Regional name = [[OFC U-20 Women's Championship]] | Regional cup apps = 3 | Regional cup first = 2002 | Regional cup best = Second Place (2017) }} The '''Fiji women's national under-17 football team''' is the second highest women's youth team of women's football in [[Fiji]] and is controlled by the [[Fiji Football Association]]. ==Information== ===Football in Tonga=== Tonga's greatest football triumph to date was their triumph in the first ever Polynesian Cup held in 1993 over Samoa and the Cook Islands. Although local players have not yet made their mark on big leagues abroad, the Chief Executive of the Tonga Football Association, Joe Topou, was appointed to the FIFA Executive Committee in 2002. The Tonga association is the only sports organization on the island that employs full-time administrative staff. ===The second Goal project=== Tonga's second Goal project will develop and improve the national football academy and the associations headquarters in Atele, Tongatapu, which was built in the country's first Goal project. This development work will ensure that all of the Tonga Football Associations needs are fully satisfied. Local matches will be held at the football academy, while the administration's requirements, including the needs of players, officials and spectators, will also be covered. The football school will be transformed into a House of Football. ==Records== ===U-20 World Cup record=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !Year !Result !Matches !Wins !Draws revision.text:
'''Franjo Bučar State Award for Sport''' ({{lang-hr|Državna nagrada za šport "Franjo Bučar"}}) is the highest recognition that [[Republic of Croatia]] gives for extraordinary achievements and contributions of remarkable meaning for the development of [[sport]] in Croatia.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2006_06_71_1704.html | language = Croatian | title = Zakon o športu | author = [[Croatian Parliament]] | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 71/2006 | date = 2006-06-09 | accessdate = 2012-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2007_03_30_1035.html | language = Croatian | title = Pravilnik o Državnoj nagradi za šport »Franjo Bučar« | author = [[Ministry of Science, Education and Sports (Croatia)]] | journal = [[Narodne novine]] | issue = 30/2007 | date = 2007-03-21 | accessdate = 2012-07-15}}</ref>
This [[award]] has been given since 1991. It came as successor of awards of [[SR Croatia]]: ''Majska nagrada fizičke kulture'' and ''Republička nagrada fizičke kulture''.<ref name="mzos">[http://public.mzos.hr/Default.aspx?sec=2400 Državna nagrada za šport Franjo Bučar]</ref>
This award is given to professional and public workers in the area of sport, sportsmen, legal and physical entities the perform sports activity, as well as other entities whose work is meritorious for the development of sport.
It is named after Croatian writer and sports activist [[Franjo Bučar]], person that popularized sport in Croatia in many ways.

revision.text:
{{for|the Canadian actor|Gordon McClellan|}} {{Infobox figure skater | name= Gordon McKellen | image= | caption= | fullname= | altname= | country= [[United States]] | birth_date= {{birth-date and age|August 26, 1953}} | birth_place= [[Reading, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | hometown= | residence= | height= | formercoach= [[Slavka Kohout]] | formerchoreographer= | former skating club= | formertraininglocations= | beganskating= | retired= 1975 }}
'''Gordon Riley "Gordie" McKellen Jr.''' (born August 26, 1953) is an American former competitive [[figure skater]]. He is the 1973–75 [[U.S. Figure Skating Championships|U.S. national]] champion and placed tenth at the [[Figure skating at the 1972 Winter Olympics|1972 Winter Olympics]].
McKellen is now providing "Virtual" coaching assistance to figure skating coaches with respect to teaching technical elements of figure skating through his website at {{URL|www.gordiemckellen.com}}.
== Personal life == McKellen was born on August 26, 1953, in [[Reading, Pennsylvania]].<ref name=SR/> His parents, Leila and Gordon "Tuffy" Sr., owned an ice rink,<ref name=RE840212 /> and his father was a member of the 1940s ice skating duo, the McKellen Brothers.<ref name=Mashf/> In 1977, McKellen married American figure skater [[Kath Malmberg]], who gave birth to their two children in the 1980s.<ref name=RE840212 />
== Career == McKellen won three consecutive U.S. national titles. He was selected to represent the United States at the [[Figure skating at the 1972 Winter Olympics|1972 Winter Olympics]] and finished tenth. His highest placement at the [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Championships]] was 5th, in 1975.
Although other skaters had practiced triple axels before then, McKellen was the first skater to attempt them in public performances.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} He landed several in exhibition in 1974–1975, as King of the Lake Placid Winter Festival exhibition and during the exhibitions following his third National championship win in Providence. The triple axel was not landed in competition until Vern Taylor did it in 1978.
McKellen retired from competitive skating after the 1975 season after his coach, [[Slavka Kohout]], left her position at the Wagon Wheel rink in [[Rockton, Illinois]], where McKellen had been training. He toured with [[Toller Cranston]]'s "The Ice Show" company after turning professional.
McKellen was inducted into the [[United States Figure Skating Hall of Fame]] in 1998. In July 2001, he was banned for life from [[U.S. Figure Skating]] because of allegations of inappropriate behavior and actions with underage female skaters.<ref>{{citation |title= Grievance Report |publisher= ''Skating'' magazine |date= October 2001 }}</ref><ref name=Grievances/>

{{use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Pakistani English|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox cricket team |name= Habib Bank Limited '''{{lang-ur|حَبيب بينك}} ''|image= |colours= {{color box|Green}} |coach= {{flagicon|PAK}} [[Kabir Khan (cricketer)|Kabir Khan]] |captain= {{flagicon|PAK}} [[Ahmed Shehzad]] |founded= |title1 = |title1wins = |ground= |capacity= |owner= [[HBL Pakistan]] |website= [http://www.hbl.com/ www.hbl.com] }} The '''Habib Bank Limited cricket team''' are a [[first-class cricket]] side, sponsored by the [[Habib Bank Limited]], who have competed in [[Pakistan]] domestic cricket since the 1975-76 season.
As of mid-January 2014 they had played 378 first-class matches, with 166 wins, 70 losses, 141 draws and 1 tie.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Pakistan/Firstclass/HabibBankLimited/Team_Records/Playing_Record.html Habib Bank Limited first-class playing record]</ref> They had also played 257 [[List A cricket|List A]] matches, with 181 wins, 73 losses and 3 no-results,<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Pakistan/ListA/HabibBankLimited/Team_Records/Playing_Record.html Habib Bank Limited List A playing record]</ref> and 10 [[Twenty20]] matches, with 4 wins, 5 losses and 1 tie.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Pakistan/Twenty20/HabibBankLimited/Team_Records/Playing_Record.html Habib Bank Limited Twenty20 playing record]</ref>

{{use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = I, Tonya | image = I, Tonya (2017 film).png | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Craig Gillespie]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Tom Ackerley * [[Margot Robbie]] * [[Steven Rogers (screenwriter)|Steven Rogers]] * Bryan Unkeless }} | writer = Steven Rogers | starring = {{Plainlist| * Margot Robbie * [[Sebastian Stan]] * [[Allison Janney]] * [[Julianne Nicholson]] * [[Bobby Cannavale]] <!--PER BILLING ON THE BOTTOM BLOCK OF POSTER--> }} | music = Peter Nashel | cinematography = Nicolas Karakatsanis | editing = [[Tatiana S. Riegel]] | studio = {{Plainlist| * LuckyChap Entertainment * Clubhouse Pictures * AI Film }} | distributor = {{ubl|[[Neon (distributor)|Neon]]|30West<ref name="Distributor"/>}} | released = {{film date|2017|9|8|[[2017 Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF]]|2017|12|8|United States}} | runtime = 119 minutes<ref name=bbfc>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/i-tonya-2017| title=''I, TONYA'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=November 30, 2017 | accessdate=January 21, 2018}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $11 million<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/features/how-margot-robbie-nailed-her-landing-i-tonya-1061528|title=How Margot Robbie Nailed Her Landing for 'I, Tonya'|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Rebecca|last=Ford|date=December 1, 2017|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> | gross = $53.9 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=itonya.htm|title=I, Tonya (2017)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=July 22, 2018}}</ref> }}
'''''I, Tonya''''' is a 2017 American <!-- DO NOT ADD MORE GENRES. As per [[WP:FILM]] and consensus on Wiki film talk, we should add only the main genre specified by sources -->[[biographical film]] directed by [[Craig Gillespie]] and written by [[Steven Rogers (screenwriter)|Steven Rogers]]. It follows the life of [[Figure skating|figure skater]] [[Tonya Harding]] and her connection to the [[Tonya Harding#Attack on Nancy Kerrigan and aftermath|1994 attack]] on her rival [[Nancy Kerrigan]]. The film states that it is based on "contradictory" and "true" interviews with Tonya Harding and her ex-husband Jeff Gillooly, suggesting they are [[unreliable narrator]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-toronto-i-tonya-premiere-20170909-story.html|first=Mark|last=Olsen|title='I, Tonya' blends humour and pathos at TIFF premiere with Margot Robbie as Tonya Harding|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=September 9, 2017|accessdate=August 3, 2018}}</ref> It features darkly comedic interviews with the characters in [[mockumentary]]-style, set in the modern day,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/apr/05/mockumentary-british-comedy-tom-kingsley|title=Mockumentary hasn't killed comedy – it perfectly skewers how we live now|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=April 5, 2017|accessdate= July 15, 2018}}</ref> and breaks the [[fourth wall]].<ref name="Bell">{{cite book |last=Bell |first=Elizabeth S. |title=Theories of Performance |year=2008 |publisher=Sage |isbn=978-1-4129-2637-9 |page=203}}</ref><ref name="Wallis">{{cite book |last=Wallis |first=Mick |last2=Shepherd |first2=Simon |title=Studying plays |year=1998 |publisher=Arnold |isbn=0-340-73156-7 |page=214}}</ref> [[Margot Robbie]] (who also produced) stars as Harding, [[Sebastian Stan]] plays Harding's husband Jeff Gillooly, and [[Allison Janney]] plays Harding's mother LaVona Golden; [[Julianne Nicholson]], [[Caitlin Carver]], [[Paul Walter Hauser]], and [[Bobby Cannavale]] also star.
''I, Tonya'' premiered at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 8, 2017, and was theatrically released in the United States on December 8, 2017, and grossed $53 million worldwide on an $11 million budget. The film received critical acclaim, with major praise drawn towards the performances of Robbie and Janney.
At the [[90th Academy Awards]], Janney won for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]], while the film also earned nominations for [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] for Robbie and [[Academy Award for Best Film Editing|Best Editing]]. It earned three nominations at the [[75th Golden Globe Awards]], winning [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture|Best Supporting Actress]] for Janney,<ref name="GG" /> and at the [[24th Screen Actors Guild Awards]], it won [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Supporting Role|Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Supporting Role]] for Janney and was nominated for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role|Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role]] (Robbie).<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/sag-award-nominations-2018-full-list-1063931|title=SAG Award Nominations: The Complete List|date=December 13, 2017|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=December 13, 2017}}</ref> At the [[71st British Academy Film Awards]], the film earned five nominations, winning [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role|Best Actress in a Supporting Role]] for Janney.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-42618187|title=The Shape of Water leads Bafta nominations|work=[[BBC News]]|date=January 9, 2018|accessdate= January 9, 2018}}</ref>
==Plot== In 1970s [[Portland, Oregon]], four year-old Tonya Harding is forced to ice skate by her abusive mother, LaVona Golden. As Tonya grows up, her parents take her out of school to focus on her skating career, and she trains under coach Diane Rawlinson. Tonya rapidly becomes one of the best [[Figure skating|figure skaters]] in the United States, but is held back by her "[[white trash]]" reputation, home-made costumes and unconventional choice of performance music. At 15, she begins dating 18-year-old [[Jeff Gillooly|Jeff Gillooly]], and the two marry, but Jeff becomes abusive. When LaVona scorns Tonya for putting up with it, Tonya blames LaVona for her raising her badly.
After a dispute with Diane, Tonya fires her and hires Dody Teachman as her coach. Tonya becomes the first female figure skater to complete two triple [[Axel jump]]s in competition. At the [[1992 Winter Olympics]], Tonya fails to stick her landings and finishes fourth. Defeated, she moves in again with Jeff and takes a job as a waitress, but Diane convinces her to train for the [[1994 Winter Olympics]]. On the day of her November 1993 competition at the Northwest Pacific Regional Championships in Portland, Tonya receives a death threat and chooses not to compete. In retaliation, Jeff instructs his friend [[Shawn Eckardt]] (who says he's Tonya's "bodyguard") to send death threats to Tonya's rival [[Nancy Kerrigan]]. Tonya makes a phone call trying to locate Nancy Kerrigan's training arena and her practice times. Eckardt hires two inept crooks to attack Kerrigan after a practice session in [[Detroit]]. On January 6, 1994, Eckardt’s henchmen strike Kerrigan's knee; she cannot compete at the next day's [[1994 U.S. Figure Skating Championships|National competition]]. The hired henchmen are arrested.
Eckardt's bragging quickly leads the FBI to him. He points the finger at Jeff, who is horrified to learn that Eckardt gave orders beyond sending the letters. Tonya qualifies for the Olympic team and is in turn horrified by Jeff, realizing that she will be found guilty by association. She goes to the FBI and tells them what Jeff and Eckardt did, but they show her interview transcript to Jeff after his arrest, and he races home to confront her. She briefly speaks to Jeff, then climbs out the window, leaving him for good. Jeff implicates Tonya, saying she knew about the attack.
LaVona visits Tonya and offers her kind words; however, when LaVona asks if Tonya knew anything about the crime, Tonya reaches into LaVona's jacket pocket, finds a [[tape recorder]], and throws her mother out of her home. Jeff, Eckardt, and the henchmen are charged, with Tonya's hearing postponed until after the Olympics. Tonya finishes eighth and Nancy Kerrigan wins the silver medal. Tonya avoids jail but is banned from competitive figure skating for life. Heartbroken, she begs the judge to give her jail time but not to take away the one thing she knows how to do; the judge refuses and tells her his decision is made. Jeff acknowledges with honest regret that he ruined Tonya's career. He changes his name, remarries, opens a hair salon, divorces; he currently lives near Tonya, albeit having no contact with her, with his third wife and two children. LaVona moves to [[Washington (state)|Washington state]] and has no contact with Tonya. Tonya remarries, divorces, takes up professional [[boxing]], becomes a landscaper, house painter and deck builder. She lives happily with her seven-year-old son and third husband.
==Cast== {{Cast listing| * [[Margot Robbie]] as [[Tonya Harding]] ** [[Mckenna Grace]] as young Tonya Harding ** Maizie Smith as Tonya Harding (age 4) * [[Sebastian Stan]] as Jeff Gillooly, Harding's lover and friend, later husband * [[Allison Janney]] as LaVona Golden, Harding's mother * [[Julianne Nicholson]] as Diane Rawlinson, Harding's skating coach and Bob's wife * [[Caitlin Carver]] as [[Nancy Kerrigan]], Harding's skating rival and [[1994 U.S. Figure Skating Championships|Olympic teammate]], and the victim of the 1994 attack * [[Bojana Novakovic]] as Dody Teachman, another of Harding's coaches * [[Paul Walter Hauser]] as Shawn Eckardt, a bodyguard and friend of Gillooly * [[Bobby Cannavale]] as Martin Maddox, a former reporter * Dan Triandiflou as Bob Rawlinson, Diane's husband and Tonya's attorney * [[Ricky Russert]] as Shane Stant, hired by Jeff and Shawn to attack Nancy * Anthony Reynolds as Derrick Smith, Stant's uncle, previous friend of Eckardt, first hired by Jeff and Shawn to attack Nancy before recruiting Shane himself to injure her }}
==Production== Screenwriter [[Steven Rogers (screenwriter)|Steven Rogers]] was inspired to write the film after watching a documentary about ice skating which mentioned [[Tonya Harding]].<ref name=sagfull>{{cite interview|last1=Robbie|first1=Margot|last2=Rogers|first2=Steven|last3=Gillespie|first3=Craig|last4=Janney|first4=Allison, et al.|title=Conversations with I, Tonya [Cast and Crew]|date=December 5, 2017|accessdate=December 23, 2017|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qqysxfvC94A|work=SAG-AFTRA Foundation|publisher=YouTube}}</ref> Rogers arranged separate interviews with Harding and her ex-husband Jeff Gillooly. Both remembered the events of the [[Tonya Harding#Attack on Nancy Kerrigan and aftermath|1994 scandal]] very differently. Rogers decided, "Well, that's my way in - to put everyone's point of view out there, and then let the audience decide."<ref name=sagfull/> He later said that the film was really about "things we tell ourselves in order to…live with ourselves…how we change the [[narrative]], and then want that to be the narrative."<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/12/i-tonya-harding-movie|title=The Surreal Story of How Tonya Harding Inspired Awards Season's Scrappiest Contender|last=Miller|first=Julie|date=December 6, 2017|magazine=Vanity Fair|accessdate=August 12, 2018}}</ref>
Regarding Gillooly, Rogers stated "What's curious about Jeff is that he refused to take any money for [[Personality rights|life rights]], for his interview, for anything."<ref name="floodmagazine_49584">{{Cite magazine|url=http://floodmagazine.com/49584/in-conversation-steven-rogers-chose-the-indie-route-for-i-tonya/|title=In Conversation: Steven Rogers Chose the Indie Route for "I, Tonya"|department=The screenwriter reflects on the messiness of truth and memory, and how he worked to build a story that encompassed everyone's point of view|last=Beresford|first=Trilby|date=March 26, 2018|magazine=Flood Magazine|accessdate=August 3, 2018}}</ref> He remembered Jeff Gillooly saying that Harding was a great figure skater.<ref name="vanityfair_2017-12">{{Cite magazine| url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/12/i-tonya-harding-movie|title=The Surreal Story of How Tonya Harding Inspired Awards Season's Scrappiest Contender|last=Miller|first=Julie|date=December 6, 2017|magazine=Vanity Fair|accessdate=August 3, 2018}}</ref> According to Rogers, Gillooly also said that it was his own idea to threaten Nancy Kerrigan's ability to perform and [[Moral responsibility|took responsibility]] for his part in Harding's 1994 ruin: "he doesn't want to profit from it."<ref name="floodmagazine_49584"/><ref name="vanityfair_2017-12"/>
[[Margot Robbie]], who played Harding and co-produced the film, did not realize the screenplay was based on a real event until after she finished reading it.<ref name=sagmargot>{{cite interview|last=Robbie|first=Margot|title=Conversations with Margot Robbie|date=January 12, 2018|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=98TyMVrh8sQ|work=SAG-AFTRA Foundation|interviewer=[[Jenelle Riley]]|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=January 18, 2018}}</ref> Immediately prior to filming, Robbie flew from Los Angeles to [[Portland, Oregon]] to meet Harding.<ref name=sagmargot/> To prepare for the skating scenes, Robbie trained for four months.<ref name=sagmargot/> Heidi Munger and Anna Malkova served as skating doubles and [[Sarah Kawahara]] provided coaching and choreography.<ref name="IN171214">{{cite news|url=http://web.icenetwork.com/news/2017/12/14/263201022/|title=Kawahara crafts skating magic for 'I, Tonya'|last=Elfman|first=Lois|date=December 14, 2017|work=[[IceNetwork.com]]}}</ref><ref name="IW171213">{{cite news|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/12/i-tonya-skating-choreographer-sarah-kawahara-training-margot-robbie-tonya-harding-1201906171/|title=Training Margot Robbie to Be 'I, Tonya': Skating Choreographer Sarah Kawahara Tells All|last=Marotta|first=Jenna|date=December 13, 2017|work=[[IndieWire]]}}</ref>
Rogers wrote the role of Tonya's mother LaVona for [[Allison Janney]]; she was a longtime friend of Rogers, but the "stars had [not] aligned" for them to work together until he completed the script for ''I, Tonya''.<ref name=sagfull/> Janney said the part was one of the most challenging of her career.<ref name=sagfull/> Shortly after the film premiered at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]], she said "I think LaVona was actually a very smart woman, very articulate….She was not messing around and didn't want [Tonya] distracted….She wanted [Tonya] to know that it was going to be hard work, and knowing her daughter needed to be told she couldn't do it in order to do it was LaVona's way of saying, 'I was there to inspire her'."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/entry/allison-janney-i-tonya_us_59b57e05e4b0dfaafcf88937|title=Allison Janney's New Favorite Co-Star Is The Bird That Sits On Her Shoulder In 'I, Tonya'|last=Jacobs|first=Matthew|date=September 11, 2017|newspaper=HuffPost|accessdate=August 3, 2018}}</ref>
Director [[Craig Gillespie]] was interested in the project because "I realized it was a great opportunity to revisit the story and make a [[Criticism|commentary]] about [[Media ethics|how the media treats people]]."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.straight.com/movies/1015946/director-craig-gillespie-takes-out-trash-i-tonya|title=Director Craig Gillespie takes out the trash with I, Tonya|last=Eisner |first=Ken|date=January 9, 2018|newspaper=The Georgia Straight|accessdate=August 10, 2018}}</ref> He did add that "I don't feel great about having to drag Nancy's name back into this". Gillespie said that he tried, in the film, to present Harding "in a very honest way" without "trying to pull those heartstrings…just showing you why she is the way she is."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iris.theaureview.com/interview-director-craig-gillespie-on-taking-no-prisoners-when-filming-i-tonya/|date=January 25, 2018|title=DIRECTOR CRAIG GILLESPIE ON TAKING NO PRISONERS WHEN FILMING I, TONYA|last=Gray|first=Peter|website=Iris.theAUreview.com|department=The Iris|language=en-AU|access-date=August 10, 2018}}</ref>
[[Principal photography]] began in late January 2017 in [[Macon, Georgia]], where [[Macon Coliseum]] was used as a set.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dga.org/~/media/Files/Production%20List/CPLBAFull%20pdf.pdf?531|title=Georgia: I, Tonya<!--PAGE 16-->|website=[[Directors Guild of America]]|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The Tonya Harding movie starring Margot Robbie is filming in Macon, GA next week|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2017/01/25/tonya-harding-movie-starring-margot-robbie-filming-macon-ga-next-week/|accessdate=February 7, 2017|work=On Location Vacations|date=January 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Corley|first1=Laura|title="I, Tonya" films in Macon, bringing '90s vibe to Macon Coliseum|url=http://www.macon.com/news/local/article130196134.html|accessdate=February 7, 2017|work=Macon|date=February 1, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Throughout the shoot, Robbie suffered from a [[Spinal disc herniation|herniated disc]] in her neck and had routine [[Magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]]s to ensure it was safe for her to continue filming skating scenes.<ref name="sagmargot" /> Filming wrapped in late February of that year,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sebastianstanzone.com/sebastian-stan-updates-his-instagram-i-tonya-finishes-filming/|title=Sebastian Stan updates his Instagram – I, Tonya finishes filming! – SebastianStanZone.com – Fansite for Sebastian Stan|website=Sebastianstanzone.com|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}</ref> with [[Pick-up (filmmaking)|pickups]] in Atlanta on May 16.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.projectcasting.com/casting-calls-acting-auditions/margot-robbies-tonya-reshoots-casting-call-atlanta|title=Margot Robbie's 'I, Tonya' Reshoots Casting Call in Atlanta|date=May 10, 2017|website=Projectcasting.com|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.2018auditions.com/tonya-casting-reshoots-atlanta/|title="I, Tonya" Casting for Reshoots in Atlanta -|date=May 11, 2017|website=2018auditions.com|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}</ref>
==Music== Some of the songs of the soundtrack were used in Harding's real routines, such as [[ZZ Top]]'s "[[Sleeping Bag (song)|Sleeping Bag]]". Others were selected by music supervisor Susan Jacobs: tracks from 1970s such as [[Fleetwood Mac]]'s "[[The Chain]]" or [[Supertramp]]'s "[[Goodbye Stranger]]" came from an era when music was "powerful and full" and "warm." Jacobs felt the "classic rock songs filled the picture without getting in the way of the story." Critic Emily Manning found that others, such as [[En Vogue]]'s "[[Free Your Mind (song)|Free Your Mind]]" and [[Heart (band)|Heart]]'s "[[Barracuda (song)|Barracuda]]", created "an interesting parallel between Tonya's tenacity and ambition."<ref name="id">{{cite web|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_us/article/xw4kmw/i-tonya-sets-figure-skating-to-siouxsie-and-the-banshees-and-it-works|title='I, Tonya' sets figure skating to siouxsie & the banshees (and it works)|last=Manning|first=Emily|date=January 17, 2018|publisher=i-d.vice.com|accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref> The film ends with [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]]' cover of "[[The Passenger (song)#Siouxsie and the Banshees version|The Passenger]]";<ref name="week">{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/12/11/i-tonya-soundtrack/|title=Best of 2017 (Behind the Scenes): The stories behind the best songs on the I, Tonya soundtrack|last=Rosen|first=Christopher|date=December 11, 2017|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref> Manning wrote: "There was something really right about seeing Tonya skate to Siouxsie."<ref name=id /> Jacobs said that "The Passenger" was "something obviously female and the lyrics [resonated]". The lyrics of [[Dire Straits]]' "[[Romeo and Juliet (Dire Straits song)|Romeo and Juliet]]" were also important as "they felt like the story".<ref name=week />
A soundtrack was released on December 8, 2017, by [[Milan Records]], featuring songs used in the film by various artists and tracks from the original score.<ref name=itunes>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/i-tonya-original-motion-picture-soundtrack/1318163084|work=iTunes|publisher=Apple|title=I, Tonya (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)|accessdate=January 31, 2018}}</ref>
